placeMetadata.name: Marina Beach

sources.snippet: The second longest beach in the world, the Marina Beach, runs from Fort St. George in the north to Besant Nagar in the south, a 12 Km shoreline in the city of Chennai along the Bay of Bengal. The beach is primarily a sandy beach. Activities: The major attractions/activities around the beach other than the beach itself are the beachside shops which bring a spark for the womenfolk and kids with numerous household items, decorations, wall hangings made of shells and stones, jewelry, toys, etc.
sources.shortName: Best Tourist Places in Chennai

sources.snippet: As far as beaches go, Marina beach tops the list, thanks to where it‚Äôs located. Marina beach itself is one of the iconic beaches in the state and is the longest urban beach in India. With more than 100 stalls for food and snacks, a lighthouse to watch the sunset, and several monuments all in one stretch, Marina Beach is where Chennai‚Äôs heart belongs.
sources.shortName: Madras Day: Best Places To See In Chennai

sources.snippet: 4 km from city center 1 out of 90 Places To Visit in Chennai. Marina Beach is a natural urban beach along the Bay of Bengal. The beach is stretched out to a distance of 13 kilometres making it the longest natural urban beach in the country, second largest in the world and also the most crowded beach in India with almost 30,000 visitors a day.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Chennai | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Marina Beach is a natural urban beach in the city of Chennai, India, along the Bay of Bengal, part of the Indian Ocean.The beach runs from near Fort St. George in the north to Besant Nagar in the south, a distance of 13 km (8.1 mi),making it the longest natural urban beach in the country[3] and the world's second longest natural urban beach
sources.shortName: The Leela Palace Chennai - Chennai, IN_TN Meeting Venues and Event Space

sources.snippet: Beaches in Chennai along the Bay of Bengal coast, happen to be the longest beaches in India and one of the longest in the world. Got enough time to pay a visit to this amazing place during the morning or evening?. We suggest that you should not miss out on experiencing the enthralling view of the sun setting or rising from the beach.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: It is India‚Äôs longest beach and also the world‚Äôs second largest beach with a total stretch of 12 kilometers (7.5 miles). Its long stretch of fine sand is surely the best spot to have your tan or build some sand castles. Its roaring waves and strong currents also make it a perfect place for surfers and water adventurers.
sources.shortName: 15 Things Chennai Is Famous For

sources.snippet: It was instead suggested that he build his residence near the fort on the shores of Marina beach due to space constraints.
sources.shortName: Madras Day | Walk with us into Chepauk Palace, the world‚Äôs first Indo-Saracenic structure

placeMetadata.description: Bustling urban beach featuring a long shoreline for basking & a variety of food stalls & shops.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Marina Beach, a vibrant urban oasis located just 4 kilometers from Chennai Central Railway Station, is renowned for being the second longest beach in the world, stretching an impressive 13 kilometers. This bustling shoreline is a must-visit destination in Chennai, attracting tourists and locals alike with its lively atmosphere. As you stroll along the sandy expanse, you'll encounter kite sellers and cricket enthusiasts mingling with families enjoying quality time together.
placeMetadata.address: Tamil Nadu, India

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful place , Location, View Point, It is so Amazing we had enjoyed a lot. With being longest coastal areas. We have walked a very long distance in the coastal lines to enjoy the view from different parts.

Marina Beach is truly the soul of Chennai! It‚Äôs one of the longest urban beaches in the world, and the moment you step onto its golden sands, you're welcomed by the soothing sound of waves and a refreshing sea breeze.

This place is an absolute masterpiece by nature. While in the morning with the cold air reaching and the sound of Ocean is just go mind relaxing. I give it a 4 star because of garbage and litter. Otherwise, the atmosphere of the place is extremely good. Best place to picnic or just explore and swim in water. The ocean was kinda salty too.

Weekend Trip Review: This location offers beautiful scenery and is a pleasant place to visit on weekends. However, significant improvements are needed in maintenance and hygiene. Despite these shortcomings, the overall beauty of the area makes it worthwhile.

Marina Beach is Chennai‚Äôs most vibrant spot always crowded, always alive. If you‚Äôre alone but want to be surrounded by people, this is the place. Expect food carts, toy stalls, rides for kids, and even horse rides along the sand. Be ready to walk about 600 meters on the beach before you reach the waves the city‚Äôs noise fades only when you get close to the shore. Parking can be tough, so plan ahead. Come here for the energy, the breeze, and the joy of being part of Chennai‚Äôs crowd.

Really was really amazed to see such a big beach in Chennai. It was a famous Marina beach it is a clean beach and also very big as well.The beach length is very big,you can play any sport here.3 to 4 big stadiums can be easily fited here

Good place but overly crowded especially during evenings and on weekends. There are life guards who keep patrolling the whole time. There are various shops for sovenirs and personal items as well. I felt a strong smell of fish along with the litter and garbage in the beach. Overally fine.
The beach is very dirty because of food  vendors selling stuff on the beach side but not cleaned. But I had experienced a stunning sunrise.

placeMetadata.name: Fort St George

sources.snippet: One of the major tourist attractions in Chennai, this fort was once a British stronghold and their first garrison settlement in the country. You can explore the Clive House, the first British official residence, and attend mass at St. Mary‚Äôs Church. The museum houses more than 3600 artefacts of British rule including letters, weapons, coins, ceremonial dresses, silverware, and medals making it among the best places to visit in Chennai.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: First built by the East India Company in 1641 as its trading center and settlement headquarters, the fort was later remodeled as their administrative center. It was the first fortress to be set up in India. The fort has a number of monuments within it, one of them is St Mary‚Äôs Church believed to be one of the oldest churches built by the British in India.
sources.shortName: Best Tourist Places in Chennai

sources.snippet: Founded in 1644 and also known as the white town, Fort St George is the place from where East India Company used to work. One of the top places to know the past of Old Madras, this is also a must-visit place for the history lovers in Chennai. Currently, the place houses the Tamil Nadu legislative assembly and different more official buildings.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Historical Places in Chennai (2022)

sources.snippet: When in Chennai, check out Fort St. George, one of the best places to see in Chennai. Additionally, the flagstaff of Fort St. George is the tallest structure in India.

reviews.reviewText:
Well maintained and systematic presentation of displays. All sections are artistically decorated to give the best look. History, Anthropology and children building components of museum are worth visiting.
A library in the centre of museum is another well maintained spot.
Overall excellent. Of course,we could see a part of presentations in 3 hours. Full viewing needs almost full day.
Only thing, which I found at the ticket counter missing was online mode of payment. In this age of technology, museum management must review mode of online payment at reservation counter in place of cash payment for purchase of tickets

Nice and expansive museum with multiple buildings and galleries.
The buildings themselves are beautiful.
Good collection of art and historical artifacts especially of the Dravidian kingdoms.
The Bronze gallery is brilliant.
But the maintenance is slightly poor in the galleries especially in the natural history part and a lot of galleries were closed when we visited in April 2025.
There is a public library also in the campus.

Overall a good place to visit but hope that they improve the overall maintenance of the museum.

The museum ticket is cash only. They don't accept any other mode of payment.

The place is not too bad. The atmosphere here is very nice. There are trees all around and the weather is cool. The library here is very good. This was my personal experience.  I would say everyone should travel, everyone should gain an experience for themselves. Come back at least once.

The Government Museum in the heart of central Chennai is a fascinating place, home to an impressive yet often overlooked collection of history and culture. Unfortunately, the space suffers from poor maintenance. The aesthetics are far from inviting, and the information provided is neither clear nor well-presented, which takes away from the experience. At present, it feels more like a neglected public space than a celebrated cultural landmark. I sincerely hope the government takes steps to revitalize it, perhaps even by collaborating with private partners, so that this treasure can be preserved and appreciated as it truly deserves.

The museum consists of several locations located nearby, which can be visited with one ticket. Fine art, bronze sculptures, a hall of ancient times. It will take about 4 hours to comfortably leisurely walk around everything and enjoy the exhibits and relax in a lively location between the buildings. I was glad to see paintings by Indian artists (though you can't take pictures in these halls), find a portrait of Gandhi, known from banknotes. I was also interested in watching the recreation of the life of ancient people and, of course, examining the building itself: doors, stained glass windows, roof. I recommend visiting! Closed on Fridays.

Nominal fee.. tons of knowledge! There are 6 museum/art galleries in this for 1 ticket.

This is the erstwhile Victoria Memorial Hall built in 1909. The entire enclosure houses contemporary art gallery, children's museum, cafeteria and resting place, a park, archaeological museum and everything under the sun!!

You'll need a half day to cover everything. Worth a visit!

We went to the museum on Sunday. The entry ticket was ‚Çπ50 for adults and ‚Çπ25 for children. For foreigners, they charge ‚Çπ250. The building was beautiful and there were many things to see. There were separate sections in different buildings ‚Äî like coins, bronze statues, and paintings. The main building has a whale skeleton and skeletons of other animals and birds. Some insects and snakes are also preserved there.

The Egmore Museum is a true gem in the heart of Chennai. Its vast and diverse collection-from ancient sculptures and bronze statues to archaeological marvels and natural history exhibits- offers a fascinating journey through India's rich heritage. The museum is beautifully maintained, and each gallery tells a compelling story that leaves you enriched and inspired. A must-visit for history lovers, students, and anyone curious about our cultural roots. Truly one of Chennai's proudest landmarks!üôåüèª

sources.snippet: Marundeeswarar Temple is a temple dedicated to Hindu deity Shiva, located in Thiruvanmiyur, Chennai adjacent to the beach of Bay of Bengal. It is one of the 275 Paadal Petra Sthalams, where the three of the most revered Nayanars (Saivite Saints), Appar and Tirugnana Sambandar have glorified the temple with their verses during the 7th-8th century. The temple has been widely expanded by Chola kings during the 11th century.The temple has two seven tiered gateway towers, a huge tank, with the overall temple area covering 1 acre.

Amman: Tiripurasundari.

The Marundeeswarar temple has been a place of curative worship for people with diseases.

Marundeeswarar is known so because he imparted sage Agastya on curative properties of various herbs and plants.Since then the Marundeeswarar temple has been a place of worship for people with diseases and various problems with their health.It is said that sage Valmiki, who wrote Ramayana, worshiped Shiva in the temple.Since Valmiki was blessed here, the place was to be known as Thiruvalmikiyur, which is pronounced as 'Thiruvanmikiyur' in Tamil, the name gradually changed to Thiruvanmiyur. There is a place present in Thiruvanmiyur called Valmiki Nagar in his honour.

Arulmigu Marundeeswarar Temple, Thiruvanmiyur (Chennai)
Visited this majestic Shiva temple and felt completely rejuvenated by its serene and healing atmosphere.

Highlights & History

The temple is an ancient Paadal Petra Sthalam, praised by Saivite saints Appar and Sambandar in the 7th century  .

Originally built during the Pallava era and expanded by Chola and Vijayanagara rulers, its current structure dates back over 1,000 years  .

Known as ‚ÄúMarundeeswarar‚Äù (Lord of Medicines), legend says Shiva taught sage Agastya the healing secrets of herbs here  . Devotees still seek blessings for health.

Sage Valmiki and other saints like Bharadwaja, Markandeya, and even the celestial Kamadhenu cow are all connected to this temple‚Äôs lore  .

Architecture & Deity

The temple sits on about 1 acre, with two grand seven-tiered gopurams on East Coast Road and West Tank Street  .

Inside, a large mandapam with 36 intricately carved pillars houses the serene Somaskanda form of Shiva, alongside shrines for Tripurasundari (Parvati), Murugan, Ganesha, Dakshinamurthy, and others  .

The self-manifested (swayambhu) Shiva Linga, called Palvannanathar, stands facing west ‚Äî a rarity among Shiva temples  .

Visitor Experience

The temple exudes a calm, spiritual energy. Devotees come here seeking healing and peace, often taking ritual dips in its sacred tank  .

It hosts six daily rituals and twelve annual festivals, including Panguni Brahmotsavam and Maha Shivaratri  .

After a recent ‚Çπ75 lakh renovation (2020 Kumbhabhishekam), the temple is beautifully maintained and vibrant  .

In summary, the Marundeeswarar Temple is far more than a historic structure ‚Äî it feels like a living sanctuary of spiritual healing and timeless devotion. A definitive must-visit on Chennai‚Äôs temple trail.

A unique feature of the temple is the sacred tree (Sthala Vriksham) under which Lord Shiva is believed to have given darshan. The space around the tree feels calm and spiritually powerful ‚Äî a perfect spot to sit peacefully for a few minutes.

The temple is spacious, well-maintained, and offers a serene experience, especially on weekdays. It's a great place to escape from the hustle of the city while still being in the heart of Chennai.

Note: There are a few stray dogs outside the temple premises. They usually stay around the entrance and can be aggressive at times ‚Äî it's best to stay cautious and avoid approaching them.

A must-visit for anyone seeking a spiritually enriching experience in Chennai.

Parking of vechile is available with a cost of 50

Such a beautiful temple the only challenge was to park your car. It‚Äôs on the main road and you have to keep your car on running road. I was surprised local person was not aware of the temple as the map location was slightly incorrect. But had a good experience. I went to weekend and it was crowded.

This massive Hindu deity Shiva temple situated in Tiruvanmayur offers the best sense of spiritual realisation. The presiding lord Marundheeshwarar is considered to have known for imparting  sage Agastya with curative properties of various herbs and plants.  Since then the temple has been a place of worship for people with diseases and various problems with their health, purely a belief that is followed by masses.

The temple is believed to have partial feature of Pallava dynasty and partially with Chola art.

One of the oldest temples of South India estimated to be 1300 years old, the temple complex is maintained neat and clean.  Houses many other sannadhis of god/goddess, with a large temple pond and an ancient tree that has significance.  There are few olden days stone carvings kept in the inner circumference of the temple.  Dont miss from seeing them...they can tell you how old the structure is. A must visit temple in Chennai.

Clicking pictures of deities is prohibited.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva known for its spiritual and healing power. Area is huge and well maintained. Mural paintings on the walls of rooftop is amazing.

Visiting Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple was a very peaceful and divine experience for me. The calm atmosphere inside the temple instantly made me feel blessed and at ease. I was truly amazed by the beautiful architecture and the spiritual energy of the place. I left with a sense of positivity and inner peace, and I would love to visit again.

Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple is an ancient and sacred temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, worshipped here as Marundheeshvarar ‚Äì the God of Medicine. It is believed that Sage Valmiki and many saints worshipped here, and that prayers offered at this temple bring relief from illness and promote good health.

The temple has a very traditional and serene atmosphere, with beautiful architecture and carvings that reflect the Chola period. The main deity, Lord Shiva in the form of Marundheeshvarar, along with Goddess Tripurasundari, radiates immense divinity. The temple is also associated with healing powers, making it spiritually unique.

Daily poojas and abhishekams are performed with devotion, and festivals such as Shivaratri, Pradosham, and Navaratri are celebrated in a grand manner. The temple premises are clean, well maintained, and the priests are helpful in guiding devotees.

Visiting Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple is not just a spiritual experience but also a journey into history, culture, and divine healing. It is truly a must-visit temple for devotees of Lord Shiva and for anyone seeking peace, health, and blessings. üôè‚ú®

This is a stunningly beautiful Armenian Orthodox Church built in 1712.  From the outside you won't even know that such a beautiful church exists, as the street outside is very busy and congested and the church's exterior wall and the main entrance may not be easily identifiable.  Even the street vendors outside wrongly directed me to the catholic church nearby when I asked them about the Armenian church!! The place is maintained extremely neat and clean. It is a different feeling when you step inside the compound and as you walk past the main entrance the chaos of the busy city vanishes and you are suddenly transported into a different place altogether like a time traveler!! The place is very calm and quiet unlike the noisy and chaotic streets just outside!!! The caretaker informed that the church is open to all and anyone can come and pray. There is no regular mass at this church. It is maintained by a few Armenian families in Chennai. If you enjoy peaceful and calm places of worship, then this place is a must visit place for you!!!

Visiting this church on the other hand will give one an experience to visit 200-300 year old Armenian Cemeteries.

This is really awesome, a very beautiful Eastern Orthodox church built in 1712, hidden from view in a lush floral court and for some strange reason not in my Rough Guide, much more beautiful than the more popular and younger Saint Thomas which is also worth a visit.
This church is a highly recommended to visit atleast once , we can learn more  about the history ,

reviews.reviewText:
Chennai International Airport  is one of India‚Äôs busiest and most important gateways, especially for travelers heading to and from South India. Located in Tirusulam, about 20 kilometers from the city center, the airport comprises two main terminals: one for domestic flights and another for international travel.

The airport has seen significant upgrades in recent years, with efforts to modernize its infrastructure and improve passenger experience. The newer sections of the terminal offer better lighting, expanded seating, cleaner washrooms, and improved signage. However, parts of the airport, especially in the domestic terminal, still feel dated and can get overcrowded during peak hours.

In terms of amenities, the airport offers a decent selection of food outlets, both local and international, as well as a few duty-free stores and lounges. Free Wi-Fi is available, though the connection can sometimes be patchy. Security and immigration processes, while thorough, are known to be slow during busy periods, which can be frustrating for travelers.

Connectivity to the city is fairly good, with options such as taxis, app-based cabs, and a metro station nearby, although the walk from the terminal to the metro could be more convenient, especially with luggage.

Overall, Chennai International Airport is functional and steadily improving. With ongoing expansion projects, it has the potential to become a more efficient and comfortable travel hub in the coming years.

Review 1 (4 Stars - Positive, focusing on connectivity and recent improvements)

Title: Improved Experience with Great Connectivity!

Chennai International Airport has definitely stepped up its game! My recent travels through MAA have been much smoother. The new facilities are a welcome change, and the overall cleanliness has improved significantly. What truly stands out is the excellent connectivity to the city via the Metro. It's incredibly convenient to reach the airport and get into the city without hassle. While there can still be queues during peak times, the staff are generally polite and helpful. A good experience overall, making it a reliable gateway to Chennai.

Chennai International Airport is truly impressive ‚Äì beautifully designed with a perfect blend of modern interiors, traditional temple-inspired architecture, and a refreshing touch of nature. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful, making the experience warm and welcoming. The airport is neat, well-maintained, and thoughtfully organized, with a spacious baggage claim area that ensures smooth travel. Even the washrooms are very neat and clean and with no bad smell. Every part of the airport is worthy of a selfie. So this is a wonderful gateway to Chennai and India!

The domestic terminal at Chennai Airport has improved a lot and offers a smooth travel experience. The check-in and security process is well organized, staff are polite and helpful, and the facilities are clean and well maintained. There are plenty of food and shopping options to keep you comfortable while waiting for your flight.

The terminal is spacious, signage is clear, and baggage handling is efficient. Overall, it‚Äôs a hassle-free and pleasant experience compared to many other busy airports.

A well-managed airport that truly makes traveling through Chennai convenient and comfortable. Highly recommended!

First time visiting Chennai International Airport and I‚Äôm genuinely impressed.
The airport is spacious, well-maintained, and efficiently managed. The facilities are modern and traveler-friendly, with clear signages and organized security checks. The terminal feels bright and open, offering a smooth experience from arrival to boarding. Clean washrooms, ample seating, and a good selection of food and retail options added to the comfort.

Chennai International Airport is one of the busiest airports in South India and offers a comfortable travel experience. The airport is well-structured with both domestic and international terminals conveniently connected. Check-in counters and security checks are generally smooth, and staff are courteous and ready to assist.

Inside the terminals, the cleanliness and maintenance are commendable. Seating arrangements are good, and the air conditioning keeps the environment comfortable even during peak hours. The airport provides a wide range of food courts, coffee shops, and restaurants serving both South Indian and international cuisines, making it convenient for travelers during long waits.

There are also several duty-free shops, convenience stores, and lounges, which add to the comfort. Clear signboards and digital screens make navigation easy, even for first-time travelers. Facilities like baggage handling, restrooms, currency exchange, and prepaid taxi counters are well managed.

Accessibility is another strong point‚Äîthe airport is connected to the city by taxis, metro, and buses, making onward travel easy. Overall, Chennai Airport provides a safe, clean, and efficient travel experience and continues to improve with modern upgrades.

reviews.reviewText:
The MA Chidambaram Stadium, fondly known as Chepauk Stadium, is one of the most iconic and historic cricket venues in India. Located in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, it holds a special place in the hearts of cricket fans due to its deep-rooted legacy and passionate crowd.

Stepping into Chepauk feels like walking into a temple of cricket. The energy is electric, especially during IPL matches when the yellow sea of Chennai Super Kings fans brings the stadium to life. The roar from the stands when MS Dhoni steps onto the field is truly spine-tingling and something every cricket enthusiast should experience at least once.

The view from the stands is excellent, with well-maintained seating and a layout that gives most spectators a clear view of the action. The upgraded infrastructure and new pavilions have improved the overall comfort and experience. Facilities like clean restrooms, food courts, and accessible entry points make it convenient for families and fans of all ages.

What sets Chepauk apart is the knowledgeable crowd. Fans here appreciate the game beyond just boundaries and sixes ‚Äî even a well-bowled dot ball or a defensive stroke can earn applause. This respect for the sport creates a unique and respectful atmosphere that resonates with players and fans alike.

The stadium is also easily accessible by public transport and offers a great location close to Marina Beach, making the visit even more enjoyable.

In short, Chepauk Stadium is not just a place to watch cricket ‚Äî it's a place to feel cricket. For any die-hard fan, witnessing a match here is nothing short of a dream. The legacy, passion, and pure love for the game make it one of the best stadiums in the country.

I've had the chance to visit the iconic M. A. Chidambaram Stadium twice to watch Chennai Super Kings in action, and each time was electrifying. The atmosphere is absolutely unbeatable ‚Äî the sea of yellow, the deafening cheers for Dhoni, and the pure cricket fever make it a one-of-a-kind experience for any fan.

The stadium itself has a historic vibe and decent facilities. Seating was comfortable enough, though certain stands can get quite hot during day matches. The crowd energy is what makes the place come alive ‚Äî every boundary and wicket is celebrated like a festival.

Entry and exit were managed decently, though it gets a bit chaotic with the crowd. Snacks and refreshments are available, but a bit pricey and the queues can be long.

Overall, if you're a CSK fan or just love live cricket, this stadium should definitely be on your bucket list. Watching a match here is not just about the game ‚Äî it‚Äôs about being part of the yellow army!

M. A. Chidambaram Stadium, commonly known as Chepauk Stadium, is one of India's most historic cricket venues, located in the Chepauk area of Chennai.  Established in 1916, it is the second-oldest international cricket stadium in the country still in use, after Eden Gardens in Kolkata  . The stadium has a seating capacity of approximately 50,000 spectators  . It has witnessed numerous significant cricketing events, including India's first-ever Test victory in 1952 against England and the second-ever tied Test match in cricket history during the 1986 India-Australia series  . The pitch at Chepauk is known to favor spin bowlers, making matches here particularly engaging.  The stadium serves as the home ground for the Tamil Nadu cricket team and the Chennai Super Kings in the Indian Premier League  . Located near Marina Beach, the stadium is easily accessible via public transportation, including the Chepauk MRTS railway station  . Its rich history and vibrant atmosphere make it a must-visit for cricket enthusiasts.

reviews.reviewText:
Chennai Lighthouse stands tall on Marina Beach, offering stunning coastal views.
It‚Äôs one of the few lighthouses in India open to the public with an elevator.
The panoramic view of the city, sea, and beach from the top is truly memorable.
Evenings are the best time to visit, with sea breeze and sunset colours all around.
The small museum inside traces the history of lighthouses and maritime Chennai.
A calm, breezy spot perfect for photography, relaxation, and enjoying the Marina vibe.

It's an amazing idea to build a lighthouse at Marina beach. The view is amazing for the top floor. But there are a lot of points of improvement.

There is only one lift. It is old and slow. A 10 floor building should have a modern and faster lift.

The space on the top is very narrow. They can accommodate only 20 people max at one time. They give only 10 minutes to enjoy the views.

I had several doubts. Why are they not using other floors to allow people to enjoy the view. If they can only use the top floor, then they should have built it bigger to accommodate more people.

The idea of a lighthouse is good but execution is very poor. It feels better to have something than have nothing.

The Chennai Lighthouse is a great place to visit, especially for those who enjoy scenic views. The entry fee is quite reasonable‚Äîjust ‚Çπ20 for Indian adults. However, in my opinion, the viewing time at the top is limited to only 5‚Äì10 minutes, which feels too short. It would be much better if visitors were allowed more time to enjoy the panoramic view from the top.

üåä Chennai Lighthouse
I visited the Chennai Lighthouse recently, and honestly, I didn‚Äôt expect to be this amazed. Located right on Marina Beach, it gives you one of the best aerial views of the Bay of Bengal. Once you take the elevator up (yes, thankfully no climbing!), you‚Äôre greeted with a wide open view of the beach, the sea, and the city stretching far beyond and the sea breeze up there is super refreshing, especially during the evening.
üì∏ Tip: Go during sunset for the best experience.

The¬†Government General Hospital¬†was established on 16 November 1664 to treat soldiers of the¬†British East India Company.[1]Mary Scharlieb¬†graduated from Madras Medical College in 1878.

In 1996, when the metropolis of¬†Madras¬†was renamed as Chennai, the college was renamed the¬†Chennai Medical College. It was later re-renamed back to the Madras Medical College, since the college was known worldwide by the older name.

The foundation stone for the new building of the college was laid by Honourable Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu, Dr. Karunanidhi, on 28 February 2010.

In January 2011, the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu Dr.Karunanithi issued a G.O. and renamed the hospital as Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital.

new campus with a six-storeyed building for Madras Medical College was built on a land covering 325,000 square feet (30,200¬†m2) on the erstwhile central prison premises in 2010 and was completed in 2012. The campus will have nearly 1,250 students and 400 faculty and staff members. The campus was built at a cost of¬†‚Çπ¬†566.3 million. Once the new campus starts functioning in late 2013, the existing MMC buildings will house the college of pharmacy, school of nursing and also accommodate students of the recently added courses of audiology, speech learning and pathology, radio therapy and radio diagnosis..

reviews.reviewText: Happen to visit this place with friends. Brings back fond memories. Awesome time in this wonderful Mahal!

Amir Mahal is the official residence of the titular Nawab of Arcot and his family. Situated in Royapettah, a suburb in the present Chennai India, it was constructed in Indo-Saracenic style in 1798. Amir Mahal has been the residence of the family since 1876. The Nawab‚Äôs successor, Mohammed Abdul Ali, and his three brothers still live in the palace with their families. It also has a mini cricket ground which is currently being renovated by the government.

The Amir Mahal was constructed in 1798 by the British East India Company to house administrative offices of the company. When the Carnatic kingdom was annexed by the Company in 1855 as per the Doctrine of Lapse, the Chepauk Palace which was the official residence of the Nawabs was auctioned off and purchased by the Madras government.
The Nawab moved to a building called Shadi Mahal on Triplicane High Road and lived there. However, the British felt that the Shadi Mahal was not a place ‚Äòfit for the residence of the Prince of Arcot‚Äô and granted him the Amir Mahal in Royapettah. Robert Chrisholm was given the task of converting the office building into a palace.
In 1876, the Nawab moved in with his family into the Amir Mahal.

The Amir Mahal has since been the residence of the Nawabs of Arcot.

reviews.reviewText:
Presidency College is an arts, law and science college in the city of Chennai in Tamil Nadu, India. Established as the Madras Preparatory School on October 15, 1840 and later, upgraded to a high school and then, graduate college, the Presidency College is one of the oldest government arts colleges in India. It is one of the two Presidency colleges established by the British in India, the other being the Presidency College, Kolkata.. At the behest of Sir Thomas Munro, a Committee of Public Instruction was formed in 1826. In 1836, the duties of the Committee were taken over by a "Committee of Native Education". The plans drawn up by the Committee did not commend themselves to the Governor of Madras, Lord Elphinstone, who in turn proposed nineteen resolutions which were passed unanimously.[1]
As first Principal, the choice of Elphinstone fell on E. B. Powell, a University of Cambridge Wrangler in Mathematics, who accepted the post. Powell reached Mumbai (Bombay) on 20 September 1840 but did not arrive at Chennai (Madras) until 24 November, the journey from Bombay to Madras taking some four weeks. In the mean time, the Committee had invited a Mr Cooper, from the Hoogly College, Kolkata (Calcutta), to carry out the duties of Principal temporarily, at a salary of Rs. 400 a month. Cooper accepted the invitation and came to Chennai (Madras). He and his staff opened Presidency School, a preparatory school, in a rented building in Egmore known as Edinburgh Home on 15 October 1840. Cooper remained in the preparatory school for only a few months. Soon after Eyre Burton Powell's arrival and before the opening of the high school department in April 1841, he returned to Kolkata (Calcutta). The preparatory School was shifted to Popham's Broadway in 1841.[1]
The schools grew into Presidency College. When the University of Madras was founded in 1857, Presidency College was affiliated to it.[1]
In 1870, the college moved to its present location in Kamaraj Salai, opposite Marina Beach.. One of the best college in Chennai. Most of the Eminent people are studied here

reviews.reviewText: Very spacious place with very bid open space in the heart of the city of Chennai. Very good place to worship. It is the Centre of the Tabligh Jamat of Tamilnadu. Neat and clean facilities of toilets and bathrooms are also there.

Tableeghi Markaz and Masjid, located at 72 A, Sattanathan Street in Choolai, Chennai, is a significant religious site for the Tablighi Jamaat movement. This mosque serves as a center for Islamic learning and community engagement, attracting both local and visiting worshippers.

The architectural design of the mosque reflects traditional Islamic aesthetics, providing a serene environment conducive to prayer and reflection.

The mosque has a spacious prayer hall that can accommodate over 3,000 worshippers, making it one of the larger mosques in the area. Its design incorporates elements that enhance the spiritual experience, such as high ceilings and ample natural light. The atmosphere within the mosque is generally peaceful, with many visitors noting the sense of community and shared purpose among attendees.

In addition to its primary function as a place of worship, Tableeghi Markaz serves as a hub for various religious activities and educational programs. Regular sermons and teachings are conducted here, focusing on the principles of Islam and encouraging personal development among the congregation. The mosque also plays a vital role in organizing tabligh missions, where members engage in outreach efforts to spread Islamic teachings within the community.

Visitors often express appreciation for the cleanliness and maintenance of the premises, which reflects the commitment of the management to uphold a welcoming environment. The surrounding neighborhood is characterized by a blend of residential and commercial spaces, contributing to a vibrant local culture.

Overall, Tableeghi Markaz and Masjid stands out not only as a place for worship but also as an influential center for Islamic education and community service in Chennai. Its role in fostering spiritual growth and unity among Muslims makes it an essential landmark in the city.

sources.snippet: One of the oldest garden houses in the city, Brodie Castle or Thendral is situated on 11 acres granted by the East India Company to James Brodie, a civil servant. ‚ÄúIn 1796, the company gave him the land on the north bank of the Adyar river on which he quickly built a large house,‚Äù says V Narayan Swami, finance director for a group of power companies which researches British history and art in India. ‚ÄúBrodie, who was part of the Scottish Brodie clan, built himself a castle in Chennai, a grand, classical house with a Scottish touch in the form of two castellated turrets.

Chennai, on the Bay of Bengal in eastern India, is the capital of the state of Tamil Nadu. The city is home to Fort St. George, built in 1644 and now a museum showcasing the city‚Äôs roots as a British military garrison and East India Company trading outpost, when it was called Madras. Religious sites include Kapaleeshwarar Temple, adorned with carved and painted gods, and St. Mary‚Äôs, a 17th-century Anglican church.
Monumental Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, known for its health & curative properties.
Founded in 1712, this church with six large bells is the site of around 350 Armenian graves.
Founded in 1916, the country's third oldest cricket stadium is home to the Tamil Nadu cricket team.
Major Indian airport with flights to other domestic hubs and international destinations.
Concrete lighthouse opened in 1977, standing at 46m & with a viewing gallery open to the public.
Pondy Bazaar, officially called Soundarapandianar Angadi, is a market and neighborhood located in T. Nagar, Chennai, India. It is one of the principal shopping districts of Chennai. Wikipedia.

ops.insert: Nanganallur or Nangainallur is one of the southern neighborhoods of Chennai, India. Since September 2011, it has become a part of Chennai Corporation. It is a residential area close to the Chennai International Airport. Wikipedia.

Adyar is a large neighbourhood in south Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India. It is among the most upscale neighborhoods of the city.
It is located on the southern banks of the Adyar River. Wikipedia.

Raja Annamalai Puram, on the Adyar River estuary, is home to Tholkappia Poonga, or Adyar Eco-Park, a forested wildlife habitat around a narrow backwater. Nearby, the Dr. Ambedkar Memorial honors a leading writer of India‚Äôs constitution in a domed pavilion, while temples include modern Ayyappan, with steps leading to its main shrine. Vast, ornate Chettinad Palace sits on the waterfront, and villas dot leafy streets.

Korattur is a neighbourhood situated in the western part of Chennai. It is a part of the Ambattur Zone of Chennai Corporation and located along the Chennai-Bangalore/Mumbai railroad about 12 km from the Chennai Central. Wikipedia.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Chennai, a vibrant city on the southeastern coast of India, is not just known for its bustling beaches and rich culinary scene; it also boasts a fascinating array of historical castles and palaces that tell the story of its regal past. From the grand Indo-Saracenic architecture of Chepauk Palace to the serene beauty of Humayun Mahal, these structures offer a glimpse into the lives of the Nawabs and the colonial influences that shaped this coastal city. Each castle has its own unique charm, inviting visitors to step back in time and explore the legacies left behind.

As you wander through the streets of Chennai, you'll discover that these castles are more than just remnants of history; they are vibrant spaces that continue to resonate with the culture and spirit of the city. Whether you're admiring the intricate designs of the Madras High Court or reflecting at the Puratchi Thalaivi Dr. J. Jayalalithaa Memorial, each site offers a blend of architectural beauty and historical significance. So, grab your camera and prepare to explore the best castles in and around Chennai, where every corner holds a story waiting to be uncovered.

sources.snippet: Beaches are almost always the best places for couples to reminisce about old memories while initiating new ones. Marina Beach in Chennai acts as the perfect alchemical setting for you to transform simple conversations into memories that you will cherish for a long time. Being one of the best places in Chennai for couple photo shoots, if you pick the right time and the spot on this beach, you enjoy the sea, sand, sun and each other without being obstructed by crowds.

In addition to that, a visit to the lighthouse and aquarium adds to the charm.

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful place , Location, View Point, It is so Amazing we had enjoyed a lot. With being longest coastal areas. We have walked a very long distance in the coastal lines to enjoy the view from different parts.

Marina Beach is truly the soul of Chennai! It‚Äôs one of the longest urban beaches in the world, and the moment you step onto its golden sands, you're welcomed by the soothing sound of waves and a refreshing sea breeze.

This place is an absolute masterpiece by nature. While in the morning with the cold air reaching and the sound of Ocean is just go mind relaxing. I give it a 4 star because of garbage and litter. Otherwise, the atmosphere of the place is extremely good. Best place to picnic or just explore and swim in water. The ocean was kinda salty too.

Weekend Trip Review: This location offers beautiful scenery and is a pleasant place to visit on weekends. However, significant improvements are needed in maintenance and hygiene. Despite these shortcomings, the overall beauty of the area makes it worthwhile.

Marina Beach is Chennai‚Äôs most vibrant spot always crowded, always alive. If you‚Äôre alone but want to be surrounded by people, this is the place. Expect food carts, toy stalls, rides for kids, and even horse rides along the sand. Be ready to walk about 600 meters on the beach before you reach the waves the city‚Äôs noise fades only when you get close to the shore. Parking can be tough, so plan ahead. Come here for the energy, the breeze, and the joy of being part of Chennai‚Äôs crowd.

Really was really amazed to see such a big beach in Chennai. It was a famous Marina beach it is a clean beach and also very big as well.The beach length is very big,you can play any sport here.3 to 4 big stadiums can be easily fited here

sources.snippet: Arignar Anna Zoological Park is, of course, one of the greatest places to visit in Chennai for lovers because it offers a green and peaceful environment, diverse wildlife, and opportunities for quiet strolls. Recently, the zoo welcomed a pair of Egyptian vultures, five mottled wood owls, and three Himalayan griffons, increasing the interest of visitors. With easy accessibility and memorable moments to capture, it is a perfect one-day outing suggestion in Chennai for couples who enjoy nature and wildlife.

sources.snippet: Yes, even grownups can have all the fun in the world when they are visiting the zoo. You will have to go a short distance to Tambaram to reach the zoo via the national highway and then walk around the zoo or even hire old bicycles to try out the vast expanse of the zoo. If you could just ignore some of the lackluster facilities then this is a great place to hang out and talk about your childhood.

sources.snippet: Popularly known as the Vandalur Zoo by locals, the Arignar Anna Zoological Park, established in 1855, is one of the largest zoos in southeast Asia. Having started with just a few hundred animals, the zoo is now home to more than 500 species of wild animals. Spread across 602 hectares of land, the zoo works toward the conservation and breeding of rare and endangered animals.

reviews.reviewText:
Had a good time visiting the Anna Geology Museum and Vandalur Zoo last Sunday. It's a great place for families and kids to explore and learn about wildlife and geology. The overall experience was enjoyable, and the place is well-maintained.

However, since April is quite hot, the walking paths get really exhausting due to the high temperatures. It would be great if more trees and shaded plant areas are added along the way to give some relief from the sun.

One concern I noticed was a deer that had escaped its enclosure and was eating human-discarded food. While it was surprising to see, it also shows the need for better monitoring and care in the deer section to avoid any risks to the animals or visitors.

On the positive side, they support both cash and QR code payments, which is very convenient in this digital age. But one important suggestion: there was no clear notice or signage informing visitors that online payment can be done directly through a QR code without standing in the ticket queue. I waited in a long queue only to be told at the counter to scan and book online via WhatsApp chatbot. This needs to be highlighted with proper boards at the entrance to save visitors' time.

Despite these small issues, the zoo offers a rich and diverse experience and is definitely worth visiting. A few improvements can make it even better!

Great zoo,home to an impressive diversity of animals. The place is huge, so it‚Äôs always fun to rent a bicycle and ride around. It‚Äôs best to come early, around 9am. It can get really hot later on, so gear up accordingly. The enclosures are a bit old, but still good enough for some nice photos and clear views.Overall it‚Äôs a fun place to spend a few hours with nature and wildlife.

Arignar Anna Zoological Park is a serene and green space perfect for a one-time family visit. The zoo has a good variety of animals, though viewing can be tricky since many enclosures are set at a distance. Navigation inside the park can be a little confusing due to limited signage, so a map or guidance would help. Overall, it‚Äôs a clean, well-kept place worth checking out if you enjoy nature and wildlife

I recently visited the zoo, and it was a wonderful experience. The place is well-maintained with clean surroundings and clearly marked pathways, making it easy to navigate. The variety of animals is impressive ‚Äî from majestic lions and playful monkeys to colorful birds and reptiles. Each enclosure is spacious and designed to resemble the animals‚Äô natural habitat, which shows the effort put into their care and comfort.

The staff were friendly and informative, always ready to answer questions. Educational boards near each enclosure provided useful details about the species, which made the visit not only fun but also very informative.

Facilities like restrooms, food stalls, and seating areas were clean and accessible. It‚Äôs a great spot for families, especially children, as it‚Äôs both entertaining and educational.

Overall, the zoo offers a perfect balance of conservation, education, and recreation. I‚Äôd definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys spending time with nature and wildlife.

Visited the zoo recently and it brought back a lot of childhood memories. Being one of the oldest and largest zoos, it‚Äôs always nostalgic and impressive. The zoo is quite spacious, with a wide variety of animals, making it a great place to spend an entire day.

A few tips for visitors: carry an empty water bottle ‚Äì there are many refill stations available, and it's best to avoid single-use plastic bottles. The entry fee is ‚Çπ200, which feels a bit on the higher side, so better maintenance and organization would be expected at that price.

Overall, it was a great experience. I enjoyed walking around and managed to capture some good pictures of the animals too.

It's not that great. It's very difficult to see wild animals like tigers and lions  because those animals are very far away to see. The distance of the entire park is also so large. But the good thing is there are cycles  available on rent. The cost of the cycle is from Rs.30 to Rs.120 (electric cycles are also available). The entry for Zoo ticket is Rs.200 for adults and Rs.50 for children. Even elephants are also staying long distance. The management should improve a lot.

Wonderful Day Out with Family or Friends!

We spent an entire day here with our family group, and it was a great experience! There's plenty of parking available, though do note that parking is chargeable. You can take a ticket either by scanning the QR code at the entrance or by paying at the cash counter.

Before entering the zoo, there's a strict check NO PLASTIC items are allowed, which is a great initiative for the environment. You‚Äôre allowed to bring food and snacks, but only in steel containers, which is especially helpful if you're visiting with kids or adults who prefer home-packed meals.

Inside, you can choose how you want to explore the place. You can rent a cycle (battery or manual) or simply walk around if you have the stamina and want to take your time. One of the highlights is the Jeep Safari for the lion visit it‚Äôs an AC vehicle and requires a separate ticket.

At the end of the visit, there's a children‚Äôs play area, along with a snacks shop and food court, making it a nice way to wind down after all the walking and exploring.

Overall, it's a well-maintained and family,friendly place perfect for a fullday outing!

I went to this big zoo on the weekend. I got in around 2:30 PM and it took me about three hours to see everything. They had bikes and e-bikes, but the lines were crazy long, so I just walked. They also had electric vehicles, which would be great for older folks. Overall, it was a good time. I thought the ticket lines would be a nightmare, but they had QR codes, so it was easy. Plus, there are restaurants and little shops, so you won't go hungry.

Semmozhi Poonga, located in the heart of Chennai near the Government Museum and Egmore Railway Station, was envisioned as a modern urban park celebrating Tamil language and heritage. While the concept is commendable, the overall experience falls short of expectations, warranting a modest 2-star rating.

**Ambience & Aesthetics (2.5/5):**
The park is built on reclaimed land that was once a degraded area, and its transformation into a landscaped garden is a step in the right direction. The name "Semmozhi Poonga" (Classical Language Park) reflects a noble intent to promote Tamil culture. There are thematic sections dedicated to Tamil literature and poets, along with sculptures and inscriptions. However, the maintenance is inconsistent‚Äîpatches of dry grass, wilted plants, and unclean water features detract from the visual appeal. The garden lacks the vibrancy and lushness one would expect from a botanical or heritage park.

**Cleanliness & Maintenance (1.5/5):**
This is where the park struggles the most. Littering is common, restrooms are poorly maintained, and there‚Äôs a noticeable lack of regular upkeep. Some areas feel neglected, with broken benches and faded signage. The fountains and water bodies often appear stagnant or non-functional, which is disappointing given the park‚Äôs central location.

**Visitor Experience (2/5):**
The park is open to the public and is often frequented by families, students, and elderly visitors looking for a green space in the city. It‚Äôs relatively peaceful compared to busier parks, but the lack of engaging activities, play areas for children, or proper seating limits its appeal. Security and lighting are adequate during the day, but it's not recommended to visit after dusk.

**Accessibility & Facilities (2/5):**
Located centrally, it's easily accessible by public transport. There‚Äôs a nominal entry fee, and security checks are in place. However, facilities like drinking water, clean restrooms, food stalls, and shaded sitting areas are either inadequate or poorly maintained.

**Conclusion:**
Semmozhi Poonga has the potential to be a cultural and ecological gem for Chennai. Unfortunately, poor maintenance, lack of visitor engagement, and inconsistent upkeep bring down the overall experience. With better management and regular care, it could rise to its intended glory. As of now, it‚Äôs a decent spot for a quick stroll, but don‚Äôt expect a well-groomed or inspiring green space.

**Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ (2 out of 5)**
*Recommended for: Casual walk, cultural curiosity. Not ideal for families or nature lovers seeking a serene environment.*

Besant Nagar Beach, also known as Edward Elliot's Beach is one of the most popular and serene beaches in Chennai, Tamil Nadu. Located in the upscale neighborhood of Besant Nagar, this beach is a favorite spot for locals and tourists looking for a peaceful seaside experience.

Highlights

Scenic Beauty: A clean and less crowded alternative to Marina Beach, offering beautiful sunrise and sunset views.

Restaurants & Cafes: The area around the beach is home to many famous eateries like Murugan Idli Shop, Jonah‚Äôs Bistro, and Mash Resto Caf√©.

The nearby Ashtalakshmi Temple and Velankanni Church attract visitors for spiritual experiences.

A great place for morning or evening walks, jogging, or just relaxing by the sea.

I recently visited Besant Nagar Beach, and I must say, it's one of the most beautiful and serene beaches I've ever been to! Located in the heart of Chennai, this beach is a tranquil oasis that's perfect for a relaxing day out.

Cleanliness and Maintenance:
The beach is actually clean and well-maintained.

Scenic Views:
The beach offers breathtaking views of the Bay of Bengal, especially during sunrise and sunset. The picturesque Elliot's Promenade, which runs along the beach, is perfect for a leisurely walk or jog.

Food and Drink Options:
There are plenty of food stalls and restaurants nearby, offering a range of delicious food options and other local cuisine. Don't forget to try some of the fresh coconut water and local snacks!

Overall Experience:
Besant Nagar Beach is an absolute must-visit if you're in Chennai! Whether you're looking to relax, take a leisurely walk, or simply enjoy the scenic views, this beach has something for everyone.

Tips and Recommendations

- Best time to visit: Early morning or late evening to avoid the crowds and heat.
- Wear comfortable clothing and footwear, and don't forget your sunscreen and sunglasses!
- Try some of the local food options at the nearby restaurants.
- Be mindful of your belongings and personal safety, especially during peak hours.

Fishermen‚Äôs Colony Nearby: On one side, the beach is relatively safe, but the other side lacks privacy due to the proximity of the fishermen‚Äôs colony.

No Lifeguards: Swimming is not advisable as there are no lifeguards or safety measures.

Mostly Local Crowd: Unlike Marina Beach, this beach is mostly visited by locals, with few outsiders.

Limited Nightlife: Everything closes around 11 PM, so plan your visit early.

Summary:
Besant Nagar Beach is not a major tourist attraction, but it's a decent place for a short visit if you're nearby. Don‚Äôt expect a well-maintained or lively beach experience‚Äîthis is more of a local hangout spot with average cleanliness and basic facilities. Not recommended for those looking for a proper beach vacation.

Surrounded by lush tree growth and offering a peaceful environment with fewer crowds, it provides a serene escape for tourists seeking natural beauty and quietude. Visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls along the sandy shore while feeling the cool water and warm sand beneath their feet.

reviews.reviewText:
The best part about the restaurant is their location. The restaurant is located on one of the lesser crowded and cleaner beaches. You can sit in the outdoors and listen to the waves while you have your meal, pretty calming.
Food is great. I would recommend to go for the Iranian cuisine since that's their speciality, although they also offer other continental and Indian dishes.
Guava Barley juice and Shiraz art tea is a must, give it a try, you won't be disappointed.
I like their hummus, though pita is more like chips, not bread. I have tried all of their veg Iranian dishes and they are absolutely delicious. So are the non veg ones. You can always ask the owners for their recommendation, they are very nice and always keen on suggesting the right thing for you.

Epic burger was good, Lasagna was also nice. Chicken burger was OK but the prices were on the higher side for everything. Nice ambience but it was very humid and hot last evening with fans and Ac not working or not sufficient. Seems like they are moving to a different location to provide a better ambience

Absolutely love the view and tea of this cafe. Ideal place to go in the evening and sit outdoors. The cool breeze of the sea and sound of waves splashing on the beach is soothing!
The Shiraz special tea is really good - black tea with mint and lime.
The food is also good. I‚Äôve tried the starters like hummus, corn on toast and chicken bbq.

With a class indoor ambience and a pleasant outdoor seating, this place is worth a try. But if the food were more tastier and satisfied taste buds to a greater extent, this would have been a must visit place ... !!!

Looking for Authentic Persian food ? Go to this quaint lil restaurant in Neelangarai . Also, don't forget to order their extremely refreshing Shiraz tea & the persian ice cream. I wouldn't suggest the Baklava cake,esp if you're a baklava lover like me.

Went to this restaurant with high expectations. But not up to the mark. We ordered Chelo kabobs and could not finish it. The meat was raw. And the rice with it was promised to butter rice but there was no butter in that. If you have tried the Chelo Kabab in Peter Cat Kolkata you would be highly disappointed to taste the same in Shiraz Art Cafe. We ordered a chicken starter and another chicken dish... Both were bland hand again the meat was hard and half cooked. One üåü for food. Overall giving 3 üåü for the ambiance and good country music. The restaurant is well decorated and you can spend a lot of time there without any disturbance. Presentation of food was nice. I wish it tasted the same.

Very tasty irani food ..good ambience ..on the beach.
The owners a very friendly.. if you are a meat lover try chelo kabab with rice melts in the mouth  ..golden fried prawns was delicious..please ask for lemon tea.
Will visit again

A cozy place for a romantic lunch date. The place is filled during weekends and it's better to make a booking for table. Rates are above average and the quality and taste depends from dishes. Pastas and starters are personal preferences here.

placeMetadata.description: Modern planetarium with a 360-degree theater for a virtual tour of the night sky & astronomy shows.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: B.M. Birla Planetarium is a modern facility located within the Periyar Science and Technology Centre campus at Kotturpuram. It offers visitors a virtual tour of the night sky and hosts astronomy shows on its specially perforated hemispherical aluminum inner dome. The planetarium features 360-degree theater for an immersive experience. Additionally, it has 8 galleries with over 500 exhibits showcasing various aspects of science and technology.
placeMetadata.address: 6/22, Gandhi Mandapam Rd, Anna University Staff Quarters, Duraisamy Nagar, Kotturpuram, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600025, India

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting the Birla Planetarium and Periyar Science and Technology Centre in Chennai was a great experience. There‚Äôs a lot to see from life-size rocket models like the GSLV and BrahMos to interactive science exhibits. The 360-degree 3D sphere show was definitely a highlight really immersive and well done. I also found the weighing machine that shows your weight on different planets pretty cool.

The human evolution section with displays on early humans and Neanderthals was interesting and there were plenty of exhibits covering space chemistry and physics. The outdoor area had some dinosaur models though a few could use some maintenance. There were also some defense and technology exhibits adding to the variety. I noticed another 3D show but I didn‚Äôt have time to check it out.

Overall it‚Äôs a great place for anyone interested in space and science. Definitely worth a visit especially for students and families

It was awesome visiting this place with the kids!  Totally recommend it.  Grab the combo ticket and check out the three amazing shows.

Adult tickets are ‚Çπ60 and kids' tickets are ‚Çπ30 for the planetarium, science center, and 3D show package.  "Science on Sphere" is ‚Çπ20 for adults and ‚Çπ10 for kids.

The Planetarium can show all kinds of celestial movements.  They use special projectors to make the astronomical stuff look incredible on the dome.

Popular exhibits include the Solar System, stars, seasons, comets, and the moon landing.  There's also a cool DRDO pavilion.

The "Dawn of the Space Age" show is a mind-blowing Mirrordome+ experience ‚Äì super realistic space travel visuals.

Children's park is free of charges. For planetarium charges above 12 years of Rs. 80 and below 12 years Rs.40. Car parking Rs. 20.
3D show is amusing and the planetarium gives good knowledge about the universe too the children.
Nearly maintained. Children can spend hours here.

Birla Planetarium's ability to bring the night sky to life with its virtual tours and astronomy shows,

This place is a must visit for kids at least in their lifetime.

Virtual Tours : Explore the night sky with virtual tours that simulate astronomical phenomena

Astronomy Shows : Engage with 35 different audio-visual programs explaining cosmic phenomena, shown in English and Tamil

Science Exhibits : Discover over 500 exhibits across eight galleries, covering topics like life science, electronics, and energy

3D Science Shows : Enjoy immersive 3D experiences, including shows on dinosaurs and scientific concepts

Science Park : Explore outdoor exhibitions on scientific principles, including solar energy and wind energy.

Entry Fee: ‚Çπ35 for adults,
‚Çπ20 for children below 12 years for the planetarium;
‚Çπ25 per person for 3D shows
Bike parking ‚Çπ5

Best to buy ‚Çπ100 combo for all activities

Near by Location: Gandhi Mandapam Road

Excellent place to visit in the heart of the city specially along with kids. Very informative.

3d show, spherical show, evolution garden were great. Price is very decent.

Birla Planetarium is located right in the heart of the city. It‚Äôs a quiet place with plenty of parking available in front. The ticket prices are very reasonable ‚Äì **INR 100 for adults and INR 50 for children** covers the entire package (Planetarium show, entry, 3D show, and Sphere show). There‚Äôs also an option to buy a **basic INR 35 ticket** for only the Planetarium show.

The campus is not very large, so walking inside is easy. At the entrance, you‚Äôre greeted by an **old fighter jet (HAL HF-24 Marut)**, an **old steam locomotive**, and a **model of the GSLV rocket**. There‚Äôs also an **evolution park (Dinosaur World)**, but unfortunately, like the science and industrial play areas for kids, it isn‚Äôt well maintained.

The **real highlight is inside** ‚Äì the Planetarium and the Science Exhibition Centre. Clean washrooms are available outside, and there are gift, souvenir, and toy shops inside. Food options are limited to a small snack counter selling tea, coffee, and light snacks, so it‚Äôs best to carry your own lunch if you plan to spend the full 5‚Äì6 hours here. Do note that food and water bottles are not allowed inside the Planetarium show, but they can be deposited at the front desk.

**Science & Exhibition Centre:**

* **Ground Floor:**

* DRDO Gallery (models of tanks, battle equipment, and Tejas aircraft)
* Hall of Nuclear Power (detailed displays on nuclear power generation)
* 3D Show (10-minute dinosaur world movie with 3D glasses ‚Äì very exciting for kids)

* **First Floor:**

* Oceans Gallery
* Mirror House (fun for kids with mirror illusions)
* Indian Space Gallery (models, information on ISRO projects, and a live quiz show)
* Ramanujan Mathematics Gallery (interactive experiments)
* Heart Museum (hearts of different animals preserved in jars)
* Science on a Sphere (visual science show on a spherical display)

**Planetarium Show:**
The absolute **star attraction** ‚Äì a 20-minute immersive journey through space, stars, the Sun, Moon, and other planets. Truly fascinating, especially for children.

‚ú® **Overall:** Birla Planetarium is highly educational and an excellent place for kids interested in science, space, and technology. While the outdoor exhibits and some galleries could use better maintenance, the Planetarium and Science Centre make the visit absolutely worthwhile.

Great experience ! Very informative.  kids / students will love this place! Myst visit place in Chennai. They also have good washroom facilities , food stalls , kids play area. Ample parking . Like a very good place to spend the whole day .
The park was pretty neat and clean. Planetarium was really good and do was the 3d show and science on a sphere. The shop and galleries were a hit. Only negative was the rusted and broken projects.

reviews.reviewText:
Lovely setting by the beach. Food was excellent üëå as was the very attentive service.
Highly recommend
Day time can get very humid.. but perfect for a family or romantic dinner esp if you are seated at the front so you have unparallel sea views
A great place to dine by the beach. Food was excellent. It‚Äôs mostly South Indian sea food dishes. Though you do get Chicken items. Service is wonderful.

A dream for Seafood Enthusiasts, situated right besides the very coast, with a cozy and delightful ambience especially at the night. This sums Bay View up

Their speciality for me is the Kovalam Curry. Basically a tangy onion-garlic curry with tamarind and a bit of spice that you can order with any seafood you want- I tried it with fish and prawns. The salty sea-food taste paired beautifully with this flavourful curry.

Pair it with their idiyappams, rice and parotta. I‚Äôm not a big fan of the Parotta though. It‚Äôs a bit on the drier side and I‚Äôve had much better Parotta outside:

There aren‚Äôt too many good veg options, but their veg Kurma is amazing with idiyappam. Otherwise, the veg menu feels not worth it at all for the price. I tried a paneer starter from here which tasted terrible, overly spiced with chutney powder or something like that

But turn to seafood, the obvious speciality and this place is a banger. They serve full grills of whole fish, crabs, lobsters and prawns and also classic seafood dishes from Fish and Chips to Calamari. Both the Indian and foreign crowd that stay in this Taj will love the offerings.

It‚Äôs a Taj Restaurant so quite obviously it‚Äôs priced extremely high. But the food quality is definitely top class too so you can‚Äôt complain. The price also accounts for the amazing seaside ambience. The chef is also very hospitable and talked to us in the table.

You cannot possibly not eat here if you stay in Taj Fisherman‚Äôs Cove, or even if you visit the resort for any reason. The highlight of the entire hotel for sure.

It's a very normal restuarant but the sea view is ultimate element. Apart from that it's a as usual fine dine.
But price of the dishes served are very costly. For two members it costs 8500
Yesterday I went to bay view resort it was amazing..ambience and food is too goog  service also excellent..

Bay View offers a wonderful dinner experience with a great sea view and lovely ambience. The service was warm, and the overall setting made for a relaxed evening. The only downside was that the South Indian curries didn‚Äôt feel super fresh and seemed reheated from the afternoon preparation. Still, a good spot for the view and atmosphere.

üö®Long story short: ‚ùå‚ùåDO NOT VISIT-under any circumstance‚ùå‚ùåüöëüö®

Don‚Äôt know where to start,the place is infested with mosquitoes that were attacking us throughout the night and poorly ventilated,both our drinks were made terribly wrong,the Bellini looked like red wine as opposed to it‚Äôs peachy colour and taste and the Mango Tango margarita was an entirely chaotic disaster, tasteless and put together terribly,the liquor used is cheap,I had a headache and a stomach upset after drinking one of these drinks ü§ÆThe food was another disappointment,the panko calamari and the catch of the day which we were told was a red snapper were very subpar and disappointing.The ambience,food and drinks put us off soooooo much that we did not even dream of having dessert.One of us was nauseous just going through this experience.We wanted a nice quiet place to discuss and the experience was so terrible that we couldn‚Äôt even stand the place,let alone discuss anything.All in all,a HORRIBLY TERRIFYING experience for prices that are absolutely certainly not worth it. Disgusting.Will not be visiting again and will certainly recommend against going here to friends and family.Why have such a substandard subpar restaurant spoil the name of a supposedly decent hotel? It ruins the reputation of Taj.
View and atmosphere was great. Service was prompt and amazing. But the food let me down.

reviews.reviewText: If you are a lover of Italian food, then this is definitely a must visit place!!!! They serve proper Italian food and I guess it is run by Italians (i am not completely sure). The menu has a wide variety of choices (Wide would be an understatement). I have tried the starters and main course. And I must say the food was simply amazing and extremely delicious. To be frank i enjoyed every single bite. They have a squid starter and without a second thought I can say that it was the tastiest squid dish i have ever tasted and I would also include it in the list of the best dishes i have ever had. I loved everything that I ordered. They also serve yummy pizzas with a variety of choices . I enjoyed the ambience equally. With all the fairy lights and small huts, it looks beautiful and would be an apt place for a romantic dinner date. Bella ciao is undoubtedly one of the best hotels i have ever been to !!! I would suggest all italian food lovers to please visit this place and enjoy the food and the ambience üòäüòä

Its a nice place to hangout with friends. The ambiance is amazing but too costly to make a hole in your pocket. Also the pizza I ordered didn't have any taste. Probably next time would try ordering something else.

The place is located at the ECR Beach. The ambiance has open air and full greenery around. It's quite a romantic place to go with your gf/bf.
The menu has good of variety of Italian dishes. The service is really nice.
We ordered Pizza and some Italian chicken dish. It was too good. Pizza was wood fired. The quantity was sufficient.
It is on an expensive side though.
Overall a very good experience.
Good ambiance, traditional brick over for pizza and bread, you can watch it live. Great non-veg food. Beef tenderloin and lamb chops are awesome. Vegetarians won't enjoy much. Desserts are ok.
Amazing ambience reminiscent of Pondicherry or Goa. Run since 1998 by some Italian women. They were considerate and the pancakes here were the best we had.
The food was good, authentic  and well presented. But for the price tag the hospitality of the management (not the people who are serving) needs to be warmer.

Great Ambience.. Delicious Italian Pastas and Mojitos. I just loved the idea of a Candle light dinner on a Beach side restaurant with excellent Music. You can just visit this place for the way the customers are being taken care off. Excellent Customer Service !!!

Perfect place, excellent food! If you're looking for authentic Italian food, then this is the place for you! Owner is very friendly and staff is also polite. Bit overpriced if compared to the ambience provided, but the taste is worth it!

placeMetadata.name: Government Museum Chennai

sources.snippet: The Government Museum in Egmore in Chennai is a treasure trove for art and history fanatics alike. This museum is one of the oldest in India and has an extensive collection of historical artefacts spanning various eras. It has a large repository of diverse exhibits ranging from art, archaeology, anthropology, numismatics, and ancient sculptural specimens.

If the two of you have an interest in human history and culture, the Government Museum is the right place to start the first conversation. Admire the architecture of the building, see the numismatic collections in the museum, there‚Äôs so much to learn here.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled within the sprawling 16-acre Pantheon Complex, the Government Museum Chennai is a treasure trove of art and history that dates back to its establishment in 1851. This museum features an eclectic mix of collections, including Indian art and sculpture, bronzes from the illustrious Chola Dynasty, and fascinating anthropological artifacts. Visitors can explore various buildings like the Museum Theatre with its stunning Italianate architecture and the Indo-Saracenic National Gallery of Art facade.
placeMetadata.address: Pantheon Rd, Egmore, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600008, India

reviews.reviewText:
Well maintained and systematic presentation of displays. All sections are artistically decorated to give the best look. History, Anthropology and children building components of museum are worth visiting.
A library in the centre of museum is another well maintained spot.
Overall excellent. Of course,we could see a part of presentations in 3 hours. Full viewing needs almost full day.
Only thing, which I found at the ticket counter missing was online mode of payment. In this age of technology, museum management must review mode of online payment at reservation counter in place of cash payment for purchase of tickets

Nice and expansive museum with multiple buildings and galleries.
The buildings themselves are beautiful.
Good collection of art and historical artifacts especially of the Dravidian kingdoms.
The Bronze gallery is brilliant.
But the maintenance is slightly poor in the galleries especially in the natural history part and a lot of galleries were closed when we visited in April 2025.
There is a public library also in the campus.

Overall a good place to visit but hope that they improve the overall maintenance of the museum.

The museum ticket is cash only. They don't accept any other mode of payment.

The place is not too bad. The atmosphere here is very nice. There are trees all around and the weather is cool. The library here is very good. This was my personal experience.  I would say everyone should travel, everyone should gain an experience for themselves. Come back at least once.

The Government Museum in the heart of central Chennai is a fascinating place, home to an impressive yet often overlooked collection of history and culture. Unfortunately, the space suffers from poor maintenance. The aesthetics are far from inviting, and the information provided is neither clear nor well-presented, which takes away from the experience. At present, it feels more like a neglected public space than a celebrated cultural landmark. I sincerely hope the government takes steps to revitalize it, perhaps even by collaborating with private partners, so that this treasure can be preserved and appreciated as it truly deserves.

The museum consists of several locations located nearby, which can be visited with one ticket. Fine art, bronze sculptures, a hall of ancient times. It will take about 4 hours to comfortably leisurely walk around everything and enjoy the exhibits and relax in a lively location between the buildings. I was glad to see paintings by Indian artists (though you can't take pictures in these halls), find a portrait of Gandhi, known from banknotes. I was also interested in watching the recreation of the life of ancient people and, of course, examining the building itself: doors, stained glass windows, roof. I recommend visiting! Closed on Fridays.

Nominal fee.. tons of knowledge! There are 6 museum/art galleries in this for 1 ticket.

This is the erstwhile Victoria Memorial Hall built in 1909. The entire enclosure houses contemporary art gallery, children's museum, cafeteria and resting place, a park, archaeological museum and everything under the sun!!

You'll need a half day to cover everything. Worth a visit!

We went to the museum on Sunday. The entry ticket was ‚Çπ50 for adults and ‚Çπ25 for children. For foreigners, they charge ‚Çπ250. The building was beautiful and there were many things to see. There were separate sections in different buildings ‚Äî like coins, bronze statues, and paintings. The main building has a whale skeleton and skeletons of other animals and birds. Some insects and snakes are also preserved there.

The Egmore Museum is a true gem in the heart of Chennai. Its vast and diverse collection-from ancient sculptures and bronze statues to archaeological marvels and natural history exhibits- offers a fascinating journey through India's rich heritage. The museum is beautifully maintained, and each gallery tells a compelling story that leaves you enriched and inspired. A must-visit for history lovers, students, and anyone curious about our cultural roots. Truly one of Chennai's proudest landmarks!üôåüèª

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: VGP Universal Kingdom is a sprawling amusement park located in Chennai, known for its extensive range of entertainment options suitable for all age groups. Established in 1975, this expansive 45-acre park features over 50 amusement rides, a private beach, petting zoo, and three restaurants. Visitors can enjoy live shows encompassing music, dance, theater, and puppetry. The park offers an exhilarating mix of thrilling rides and water attractions alongside entertaining live performances throughout the year.
