State collections including Indian art & sculpture, bronzes, anthropology & a children's section.
Vegetarians & meat eaters are both catered for in this stylish Euro restaurant with wooden tables.
Restaurant with global cuisine, well-known for brunch, with some tables overlooking a garden.
Large amusement park with rides & a water area with slides & a wave pool, plus 2 restaurants.
Sizable complex featuring a range of retailers & restaurants, plus cinemas & a boutique hotel.
Indoor attraction featuring manmade snow, sledding, a mountain for climbing & upbeat music.
Cross cultural museum featuring 18 historical houses, along with art, crafts & performances.
Intimate rooftop restaurant serving regional Mediterranean dishes at an upscale hotel.
Indian & globally inspired grill fare served in an elegant venue with a tranquil garden area.

Besant Nagar is an upscale, coastal neighborhood with a lively vibe. Landmarks around sandy Elliot‚Äôs Beach include the Sri Ashtalakshmi Temple, dedicated to the 8 avatars of Goddess Lakshmi, and the Karl Schmidt Memorial, which commemorates a European sailor. Christians pray to the Virgin Mary at Annai Vailankanni Shrine. Near the beach, relaxed cafes, fast-food joints and South Indian eateries fill up with locals.
Sophisticated rooftop space at a hotel offering elevated city views & upmarket Indian cuisine.
Stylish, vintage-style cafe offering international dishes, salads & breakfast.
Large, tree-filled park with a variety of animals & greenery, plus a children's play area.

Chennai, on the Bay of Bengal in eastern India, is the capital of the state of Tamil Nadu. The city is home to Fort St. George, built in 1644 and now a museum showcasing the city‚Äôs roots as a British military garrison and East India Company trading outpost, when it was called Madras. Religious sites include Kapaleeshwarar Temple, adorned with carved and painted gods, and St. Mary‚Äôs, a 17th-century Anglican church.
Drinks and Mediterranean nibbles are served around the rooftop pool at this luxury hotel.
Popular, sandy strand known for its sunsets, plus vendors selling grilled corn & other street food.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Chennai, a vibrant city on the southeastern coast of India, is not just known for its rich culture and history but also for its romantic spots that offer a perfect blend of charm and intimacy. From serene beaches to lush gardens, this bustling metropolis has a variety of settings that cater to couples looking to create unforgettable memories. Imagine strolling hand-in-hand along the golden sands of Marina Beach as the sun sets, or enjoying a quiet dinner at a rooftop restaurant with breathtaking views of the Bay of Bengal. Each corner of Chennai has its own unique allure, making it an ideal destination for lovebirds.

As you explore the city, you'll discover hidden gems like the tranquil Semmozhi Poonga, where you can lose yourselves among the vibrant flora, or the enchanting Kipling Cafe, nestled in a colonial-era bungalow that exudes romance. Whether you're seeking adventure or relaxation, Chennai offers a delightful mix of experiences that will make your heart flutter. So pack your bags and get ready to explore the most romantic places in this captivating city, where every moment is an opportunity to connect and celebrate love.

data.title: The 50 best photo spots in Chennai (Madras)

placeMetadata.name: Marina Beach

sources.snippet: Marina Beach is the longest beach (12km) in India and the second-longest in the world ‚Äì nearly 80 miles on the coromandel coast and extends from Beasant Nagar in the south to Fort St. George in the north. A good place to go for a walk, relax, solo photography or couple shoots or just soak up the sun but you cannot swim as it is prohibited because the undercurrent is very turbulent. Nonetheless, if you are looking for beach vibes in your pictures, this could be it.
sources.shortName: Best places for photoshoot in Chennai

sources.snippet: It provides a timeless background for pre-wedding photoshoots with its golden sands, shimmering waves, and bustling promenade. The boundless length of the beach and the gorgeous Bay of Bengal provide breathtaking sights, while the energetic atmosphere adds a natural, romantic touch to your images. Capturing moments with local fishermen, joyful youngsters, and romantic sunsets will make your Marina Beach photoshoot special.
sources.shortName: Top 14 Pre-Wedding Shoot Places In Chennai

sources.snippet: Marina Beach is acclaimed as one of the longest natural urban beaches in the world. It extends over a distance of 12 km along the Coromandel Coast of the Bay of Bengal between St. George Fort in the North and Beasant Nagar in the South and is easily accessible by different modes of transport. The immaculate charm, blithesome ambiance, and diverse ecosystems make it a popular hangout for all.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Places To Visit In Chennai (2024 Updated List)

sources.snippet: 4 km from city center 1 out of 90 Places To Visit in Chennai. Marina Beach is a natural urban beach along the Bay of Bengal. The beach is stretched out to a distance of 13 kilometres making it the longest natural urban beach in the country, second largest in the world and also the most crowded beach in India with almost 30,000 visitors a day.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Chennai | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Beaches in Chennai along the Bay of Bengal coast, happen to be the longest beaches in India and one of the longest in the world. Got enough time to pay a visit to this amazing place during the morning or evening?. We suggest that you should not miss out on experiencing the enthralling view of the sun setting or rising from the beach.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: Marina Beach is undeniably one of the most popular beaches in Chennai. It boasts of being the second longest beach in the world. Marina Beach stretch is located opposite to many prominent buildings in the city such as Madras University, Presidency College, Swami Vivekananda Museum and House, AIR and various government offices.
sources.shortName: Places to Visit in Chennai

sources.snippet: Marina Beach is one of the most romantic places in Chennai where one can watch the sunrise as well as sunset hand in hand with their loved one. Both these moments create a magical feeling all around. There is golden sand on the beach everywhere with sea breeze passing through your hair making you fall in love all over again.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Romantic Places In Chennai (UPDATED 2024)

sources.snippet: One of the most instagrammable places in Chennai is a 13-kilometre-long Madras Marina - named by Governor Grant Duff in the year 1884. So long that the golden sands mix with the blue waters of the Bay of Bengal. Counted as the second longest beach in the world after Cox's Bazar Beach in Bangladesh.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Chennai

sources.snippet: This is one of the iconic places in Chennai and your trip to Chennai is incomplete without a visit to Marina Beach. The enthralling sunrises here is no less than the spectacular sunsets. This is a perfect destination for any group and a fantastic escape from Chennai's intense temperatures.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Places to Visit in Chennai

sources.snippet: For one, it‚Äôs not only long, but so wide that if you sit down, you‚Äôll think you‚Äôre in the desert instead of a beach. And two, it‚Äôs as urban of a beach as you‚Äôll find. So even if you‚Äôre not a street photographer who is interested in beaches, this would be the exception.
sources.shortName: City Street Guides by f.d. walker: A Street Photography Guide to Chennai, India

sources.snippet: Whether it‚Äôs the serene calmness of the early morning or the dramatic interplay of colors as the sun bids adieu, Marina Beach offers a canvas of natural beauty waiting to be captured through the lens. Capture this splendor effortlessly with Chennai car rental services.
sources.shortName: Chennai's Scenic Spots by Car

sources.snippet: Marina Beach of Chennai is the second longest beach in the world. It has a 12km long coastline that is enclosed with palm trees along the promenade. It is a great tourist spot where you can spot locals taking long walks and enjoying the calm sea-breeze.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places To Visit In Chennai (Madras) (2025)

sources.snippet: More than 13 km of beach attract many people ‚Äì but not for sun tanning. This is a wide urban beach which looks during noon time like a deserted island and becomes quite crowded after 3pm. This beach is the main escape space for local people.
sources.shortName: Your Street Photography Workshop guide to Chennai (2024)

sources.snippet: Special features: Longest urban beach, picturesque sunrise/sunset views, iconic lighthouse.Timings: Open 24 hoursWebsite: https://chennai.nic.in/tourist-place/marina/Location charges: No specific charges for photography.
sources.shortName: 20 Pre-Wedding Photoshoot Places in Chennai (October 2024)

placeMetadata.description: Bustling urban beach featuring a long shoreline for basking & a variety of food stalls & shops.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Marina Beach, a vibrant urban oasis located just 4 kilometers from Chennai Central Railway Station, is renowned for being the second longest beach in the world, stretching an impressive 13 kilometers. This bustling shoreline is a must-visit destination in Chennai, attracting tourists and locals alike with its lively atmosphere. As you stroll along the sandy expanse, you'll encounter kite sellers and cricket enthusiasts mingling with families enjoying quality time together.
placeMetadata.address: Tamil Nadu, India

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful place , Location, View Point, It is so Amazing we had enjoyed a lot. With being longest coastal areas. We have walked a very long distance in the coastal lines to enjoy the view from different parts.

Marina Beach is truly the soul of Chennai! It‚Äôs one of the longest urban beaches in the world, and the moment you step onto its golden sands, you're welcomed by the soothing sound of waves and a refreshing sea breeze.

This place is an absolute masterpiece by nature. While in the morning with the cold air reaching and the sound of Ocean is just go mind relaxing. I give it a 4 star because of garbage and litter. Otherwise, the atmosphere of the place is extremely good. Best place to picnic or just explore and swim in water. The ocean was kinda salty too.

Weekend Trip Review: This location offers beautiful scenery and is a pleasant place to visit on weekends. However, significant improvements are needed in maintenance and hygiene. Despite these shortcomings, the overall beauty of the area makes it worthwhile.

Marina Beach is Chennai‚Äôs most vibrant spot always crowded, always alive. If you‚Äôre alone but want to be surrounded by people, this is the place. Expect food carts, toy stalls, rides for kids, and even horse rides along the sand. Be ready to walk about 600 meters on the beach before you reach the waves the city‚Äôs noise fades only when you get close to the shore. Parking can be tough, so plan ahead. Come here for the energy, the breeze, and the joy of being part of Chennai‚Äôs crowd.

Really was really amazed to see such a big beach in Chennai. It was a famous Marina beach it is a clean beach and also very big as well.The beach length is very big,you can play any sport here.3 to 4 big stadiums can be easily fited here

Good place but overly crowded especially during evenings and on weekends. There are life guards who keep patrolling the whole time. There are various shops for sovenirs and personal items as well. I felt a strong smell of fish along with the litter and garbage in the beach. Overally fine.
The beach is very dirty because of food  vendors selling stuff on the beach side but not cleaned. But I had experienced a stunning sunrise.

placeMetadata.name: Edward Elliot's Beach

sources.snippet: With Ashtalakshmi Kovil in its vicinity, Elliot‚Äôs Beach is a famous place to visit in Chennai with friends or family. This beautiful beach, which was named after Edward Elliot (the Chief Magistrate, and Superintendent of Madras during the British Era), is one of the cleanest seafronts in India. Sunbathe, relax and unwind, keeping the stress at bay at this extremely calm and scenic place.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: South of Marina Beach, it‚Äôs another one of Chennai‚Äôs urban beaches. It‚Äôs not nearly as big as Marina Beach, but it‚Äôs still definitely worth checking out. While they share similarities, Elliot‚Äôs Beach is known as the cleanest beach in Chennai and the main street is lined with a variety of restaurants and shops.
sources.shortName: City Street Guides by f.d. walker: A Street Photography Guide to Chennai, India

sources.snippet: Elliot‚Äôs Beach is one very beautiful beach in Chennai, and what‚Äôs more, it is less dense and crowded than Marina. The sand here is brown, and very clean, while the Schmidt Memorial is a good sightseeing spot. It was built for Karl Schmidt, a Dutch sailor, and attracts visitors with its stories and beauty.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places To Visit In Chennai (Madras) (2025)

sources.snippet: Besant Nagar Beach, fondly known as Elliot‚Äôs Beach, offers a contrasting yet equally captivating setting for golden hour photography. Nestled away from the hustle and bustle, this beach exudes tranquility with its gentle waves lapping against the shore and the cool sea breeze caressing your skin.
sources.shortName: Chennai's Scenic Spots by Car

sources.snippet: South of Marina Beach, Elliot‚Äôs Beach is smaller als Marina Beach and located in the neighborhood Besant Nagar. The beaches are quite similar in some aspects, but Elliot‚Äôs Beach became famous for being the cleanest beach in Chennai. That is you perfect spot for Street Photography!
sources.shortName: Your Street Photography Workshop guide to Chennai (2024)

sources.snippet: Also known as Besant Nagar Beach, Elliot‚Äôs beach is one of the cleanest beaches in India. The Ashtalakshmi Temple we talked about earlier, is located to the south of this beach. There is an incredible Schmidt Memorial on the beach to remember the Dutch sailor Karl Schmidt.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Places to Visit in Chennai

sources.snippet: Elliot's beach popularly also known as Bessie is set towards the southern endpoint of Marina beach shore. The beach has been named after Edward Elliot, former Chief Magistrate and Superintendent of police. The dramatically sandy beach lures locals and tourists alike.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Places To Visit In Chennai (2024 Updated List)

sources.snippet: If you are looking for a secondary beach option, head to Elliot‚Äôs beach aka Besant Nagar Beach. It is very popular among the youth of Chennai as it has many restaurants, cafes, or bars to lounge in!. It is also an ideal place to relax on the sand or take a walk.
sources.shortName: Best places for photoshoot in Chennai

sources.snippet: 7 km from city center 11 out of 90 Places To Visit in Chennai. A beach showcasing beauty, calmness, serenity and everything that signifies nature at its best, the Elliot's beach cannot be forgotten by anyone who has visited it once.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Chennai | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Special features: Serene beach, calm atmosphere, scenic views.Timings: Open 24 hoursWebsite: No official website available.Location charges: No specific charges for photography.
sources.shortName: 20 Pre-Wedding Photoshoot Places in Chennai (October 2024)

placeMetadata.description: Popular beach offering a sandy shoreline & swimming spots, plus the Karl Schmidt Memorial.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Edward Elliot's Beach, also known as Besant Nagar Beach or Bessie, is a popular destination in Chennai. Named after British explorer Edward Elliot, this beach is renowned for its clean shoreline and tranquil atmosphere. Surrounded by lush tree growth and offering a peaceful environment with fewer crowds, it provides a serene escape for tourists seeking natural beauty and quietude. Visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls along the sandy shore while feeling the cool water and warm sand beneath their feet.
placeMetadata.address: Tamil Nadu, India

reviews.reviewText: Very calm and soothing experience. It was very peaceful inside. The Shia mosque has historical significance. There is a library and cemetery in the mosque premises. There is no entry fee.

The Thousand Lights Shia Mosque, situated on Peter's Road in Royapettah, Chennai, stands as one of the city‚Äôs most iconic and historic religious landmarks.

Its origins trace back to the early 19th century when Nawab Umdat-ul-Umrah of the Wallajah dynasty commissioned its construction on land previously used by Shia Muslims as a gathering place, especially during the month of Muharram.

The mosque derives its evocative name from the tradition of illuminating its vast prayer hall with a thousand oil lamps, creating a mesmerizing spectacle that has become part of local legend.

Architecturally, the mosque is a striking example of Indo-Islamic design, featuring multiple domes and tall minarets that rise prominently above the bustling Anna Salai area.

The main prayer hall is spacious and adorned with Quranic inscriptions, while separate areas are designated for men and women. The mosque complex also includes a Dargah dedicated to Imam Hussain (Raziyallahu Anhu), the revered grandson of Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫, further enhancing its spiritual significance for the Shia community.

The Thousand Lights Mosque is not only a vibrant center for daily worship but also a focal point during Muharram, when thousands gather to commemorate the martyrdom of Imam Hussain. The atmosphere during these observances is solemn, with the mosque beautifully lit and filled with the sounds of prayer and reflection.

Visitors are welcomed, provided they dress modestly and observe the decorum expected in a place of worship. The mosque‚Äôs central location makes it easily accessible, and it remains open from early morning until late evening, inviting both devotees and those interested in its history and architecture to experience its unique ambiance.

Beyond its religious functions, the mosque is a symbol of Chennai‚Äôs pluralistic heritage and serves as a reminder of the city‚Äôs deep-rooted connections to diverse faiths and traditions. Its enduring presence, historical roots, and architectural grandeur make it a must-visit for anyone seeking to understand the cultural and spiritual fabric of Chennai.

Connemara Public Library in Chennai is a treasure trove for book lovers and history enthusiasts. Established in 1896, it's one of India's oldest libraries and a national depository library, receiving a copy of all books, newspapers, and periodicals published in the country. Located within the Government Museum complex on Pantheon Road, Egmore, the library boasts an impressive collection of over 600,000 books, including rare and antique volumes.

The building itself is an architectural marvel, showcasing Indo-Saracenic, Mughal, and Hindu influences. The interior design of the old library is equally impressive, featuring:

- Intricate Wooden Carvings : The library's wooden shelves and furniture are adorned with intricate carvings, reflecting the craftsmanship of the era. The carvings depict various motifs, including floral patterns, geometric shapes, and foliage.
- Stained Glass Panels : The library's windows feature stained glass panels, allowing natural light to filter in and casting colorful patterns on the floor. The stained glass work adds a touch of elegance and sophistication to the library's design.
- High Ceilings : The library's high ceilings add to its grandeur, creating a sense of spaciousness and airiness. The ceilings are adorned with decorative moldings and plasterwork, adding to the library's ornate details.
- Ornate Details : The library's interior features ornate details, including carved wooden panels, decorative moldings, and intricate plasterwork. These details reflect the library's rich history and cultural significance.
- Period Furniture : The library's furniture, including the reading tables and chairs, is original to the building and adds to its historic charm. The furniture is made from high-quality wood and features intricate carvings and ornate details.

The library's design is a testament to the architectural styles of the late 19th century, blending different influences to create a unique and captivating space. The interior design elements work together to create a sense of history and tradition, making the library a must-visit destination for anyone interested in architecture, history, or literature.

Architectural Style

- Indo-Saracenic : The library's design reflects the Indo-Saracenic style, which combines Indian, Islamic, and Western architectural influences.
- Mughal Influences : The library's arches, domes, and minarets reflect Mughal architectural influences, adding to its grandeur and majesty.
- Hindu Influences : The library's design also reflects Hindu influences, with intricate carvings and ornate details that are characteristic of Hindu architecture.

Library Features

- Rare Book Collection : The library houses rare books, including a Bible published in 1608 AD and "Hortus Indicus Malabaricus" (1678-1703 AD publication)
- Braille Library : A special section for the visually impaired
- Periodicals Hall : A dedicated space for periodicals and journals
- Reference Room : A comprehensive room for research and study
- IAS Study Centre : A section dedicated to supporting IAS aspirants

Visiting Information

- Timings : 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM, all days of the week, except national holidays
- Entry Fee : No entry fee, but membership is required to borrow books.
- Membership : Available to Chennai residents only, with an annual fee

With its rich history, architectural beauty, and vast collection of books, Connemara Public Library is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in literature, history, or research. Whether you're a student, researcher, or book enthusiast, this library is sure to captivate and inspire.

The Connemara Public Library in Chennai stands as a venerable institution, contributing significantly to the intellectual landscape of the city. Established in 1896, its historic architecture exudes a timeless charm. The library boasts an extensive collection of books, covering diverse genres and catering to varied interests.
One notable feature is its impressive reference section, providing a valuable resource for students and researchers. The ambiance is conducive to quiet reading and study, making it a preferred haven for those seeking a peaceful retreat from the bustling city life.
The library has adapted to the digital age, offering computer facilities and online resources, enhancing accessibility for a broader audience. The staff is knowledgeable and helpful, contributing to a welcoming atmosphere. Regular literary events and book clubs further enrich the cultural experience for patrons.
While the physical space may have limitations, the Connemara Public Library's enduring legacy and commitment to fostering a love for literature and knowledge make it a cherished institution in Chennai. It continues to play a pivotal role in nurturing a reading culture and remains an integral part of the city's cultural heritage.

The Connemara Public Library, located in Egmore, Chennai, is one of India‚Äôs four National Depository Libraries, meaning it receives a copy of every book, newspaper, and periodical published in the country. Established in 1890 and opened to the public in 1896, it was named after Lord Connemara, the then Governor of Madras.

Semmozhi Poonga, located in the heart of Chennai near the Government Museum and Egmore Railway Station, was envisioned as a modern urban park celebrating Tamil language and heritage. While the concept is commendable, the overall experience falls short of expectations, warranting a modest 2-star rating.

**Ambience & Aesthetics (2.5/5):**
The park is built on reclaimed land that was once a degraded area, and its transformation into a landscaped garden is a step in the right direction. The name "Semmozhi Poonga" (Classical Language Park) reflects a noble intent to promote Tamil culture. There are thematic sections dedicated to Tamil literature and poets, along with sculptures and inscriptions. However, the maintenance is inconsistent‚Äîpatches of dry grass, wilted plants, and unclean water features detract from the visual appeal. The garden lacks the vibrancy and lushness one would expect from a botanical or heritage park.

**Cleanliness & Maintenance (1.5/5):**
This is where the park struggles the most. Littering is common, restrooms are poorly maintained, and there‚Äôs a noticeable lack of regular upkeep. Some areas feel neglected, with broken benches and faded signage. The fountains and water bodies often appear stagnant or non-functional, which is disappointing given the park‚Äôs central location.

**Visitor Experience (2/5):**
The park is open to the public and is often frequented by families, students, and elderly visitors looking for a green space in the city. It‚Äôs relatively peaceful compared to busier parks, but the lack of engaging activities, play areas for children, or proper seating limits its appeal. Security and lighting are adequate during the day, but it's not recommended to visit after dusk.

**Accessibility & Facilities (2/5):**
Located centrally, it's easily accessible by public transport. There‚Äôs a nominal entry fee, and security checks are in place. However, facilities like drinking water, clean restrooms, food stalls, and shaded sitting areas are either inadequate or poorly maintained.

**Conclusion:**
Semmozhi Poonga has the potential to be a cultural and ecological gem for Chennai. Unfortunately, poor maintenance, lack of visitor engagement, and inconsistent upkeep bring down the overall experience. With better management and regular care, it could rise to its intended glory. As of now, it‚Äôs a decent spot for a quick stroll, but don‚Äôt expect a well-groomed or inspiring green space.

**Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ (2 out of 5)**
*Recommended for: Casual walk, cultural curiosity. Not ideal for families or nature lovers seeking a serene environment.*

Wow! The crocodile park is super cool! You can see so many big, sleepy crocodiles and alligators just hanging out. Some are hiding in the water, and some are sunbathing. It's like a big home just for them! It's a super fun place to visit and see these awesome creatures up close.

A great place for kids to explore and enjoy watching crocodiles and other reptiles. The park has a clean restroom and a canteen for snacks. It‚Äôs educational and fun, but some areas need better cleaning. Overall, a good family outing spot with basic facilities and lots to see.

I was aged 8 years when I went here for the first time. Now after 42 years I visited this place again. It was a like a movie running of my childhood. Everything came back to life.

It has almost all varieties of crocodiles here lingeuth monitor lizard and turtles. All are kept separately in big enclosures mimicking there natural habitat. It was still the same as I saw in my childhood.

They previously also had lots of snakes in earthen pots and they used to do venom extraction possibly for medicinal purpose. But this time they didn't had as during this time if the year they release snakes in the wild for mating.

The entry is Rs.100 / person. It was really a nice experience being there again.

Visited this spot and had a great time spotting crocodiles and turtles in their natural habitat. Even caught a glimpse of a few snakes! It's a perfect place to spend an hour, connecting with nature and wildlife. Recommended for kids 6+

Small yet clean and interesting place. There are several types of reptiles specially crocodiles. It gets very hot during the day time. Good place for kids. Have canteen and souvenir shop. Sadly April and May snake extraction unit is shut , which was shut when we visited. Don't miss the Thor. Also there is no night Safari organised (it's closed permanently).

reviews.reviewText:
A magnificent temple dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva.. As a non Hindu, I found the guided tour of the temple and surrounding sites by our tour company Enchanting Travels to be well researched and informative and the huge temple grounds a must do when visiting Chennai.
We are here during the annual event of 2025. It was an amazing experience.

"Visited and it was truly a serene experience! The architecture is stunning, and the atmosphere is so peaceful. The priests were welcoming, and the rituals were performed with devotion. I felt a deep sense of spirituality and connection. Highly recommend for those seeking solace and tranquility. A must-visit!"

Visited Kapaleeswarar Temple recently, and it was truly a beautiful experience. The gopuram is stunning with its intricate carvings ‚Äì you can spend quite some time just admiring the details. Inside, the temple has a very peaceful atmosphere despite being busy most of the time. the chants and lamps made it feel even more spiritual.

The area around the temple is also lively with small shops and traditional food stalls, which adds to the charm. Parking can be a bit tricky, and the crowd is usually heavy, but that‚Äôs expected at such a famous temple. If you‚Äôre in Chennai, this is definitely a must-visit, both for the architecture and the divine experience.

Visiting Kapaleeshwarar Temple was a truly divine experience for me. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple‚Äôs stunning architecture and intricate carvings are breathtaking. The premises are well maintained, and the atmosphere is filled with peace and devotion. Who ever that visits this temple will definitely feel calm, blessed, and spiritually uplifted.‚Äù

It is one of the oldest and powerful Shiva temples, which is located in the middle of Chennai.
One of the best landmarks of Hinduism in Chennai.
Even though it is in mid of Chennai, inside the temple premises, you feel such a divine and spiritual attainment.
Both Shiva and Ambal Sannithi give pleasant and divine feelings.
You will feel more relaxed after getting dharshan from Shiva and Ambaal.
Mostly in the evening, cultural programmes which reflect our traditional and together chanting of the Shiva Puranam give a higher elevation of our spiritual level.

This temple is a true example of South Indian architecture. Built around the 7th century, dedicated to Lord Shiva. Whenever I visit chennai i make sure to go to this temple the aura the architecture the sculpture and the serenity of this hindu temple attracts me so much. Like Gorakhpur temple of UP here also I saw lots of idols of sadhus . Photography of idols is prohibited. This time i visited the temple early morning around 5 am still I could see good number of devotees there.  If visiting Chennai must go to kapaleshwar temple for darshan.

Kapaleeshwarar Temple, Mylapore ‚Äî a classic Chennai landmark that feels timeless the moment you pass the towering gopuram. The nadaswaram and tavil during puja, the fragrance of jasmine and camphor, and the bustle around the temple tank create a beautiful, old-Madras vibe. Darshan usually moves smoothly; priests are courteous and the premises are kept clean with clear signboards and organized footwear counters. Visit early morning or around the evening aarti for cooler weather and fewer crowds (festival days‚Äîespecially Panguni Peruvizha/Arubathimoovar‚Äîget packed). Dress modestly; photos are fine in the outer prakarams but avoid the sanctum. Parking is easiest around the tank streets.

Secret tip: after offering at Karpagambal‚Äôs shrine, step to the Punnai (temple) tree and look up‚Äîyou‚Äôll spot carvings and imagery of the peacock tied to the temple‚Äôs legend. At sunset, walk the tank‚Äôs east side for the best reflection shot of the gopuram.

One of very famous temple in Chennai , it is my first visit and had great darshan here . The management maintains the temple and its surrounding in very clean manner . All sannadhis are visible from long itself which I feel so special. Even in heavy crowd can have a good view of Mulavar from outside itself . Idols of 108 Nayanmargal around Mulavaru gives you the divine vibe . Must visit in weekdays as it is lightly crowded even on Friday odd hours . Definitely in weekends or in special occasions temple will be heavily crowded . Must visit Temple OM NAMAH SHIVAYA üôè

reviews.reviewText:
Had a good time visiting the Anna Geology Museum and Vandalur Zoo last Sunday. It's a great place for families and kids to explore and learn about wildlife and geology. The overall experience was enjoyable, and the place is well-maintained.

However, since April is quite hot, the walking paths get really exhausting due to the high temperatures. It would be great if more trees and shaded plant areas are added along the way to give some relief from the sun.

One concern I noticed was a deer that had escaped its enclosure and was eating human-discarded food. While it was surprising to see, it also shows the need for better monitoring and care in the deer section to avoid any risks to the animals or visitors.

On the positive side, they support both cash and QR code payments, which is very convenient in this digital age. But one important suggestion: there was no clear notice or signage informing visitors that online payment can be done directly through a QR code without standing in the ticket queue. I waited in a long queue only to be told at the counter to scan and book online via WhatsApp chatbot. This needs to be highlighted with proper boards at the entrance to save visitors' time.

Despite these small issues, the zoo offers a rich and diverse experience and is definitely worth visiting. A few improvements can make it even better!

Great zoo,home to an impressive diversity of animals. The place is huge, so it‚Äôs always fun to rent a bicycle and ride around. It‚Äôs best to come early, around 9am. It can get really hot later on, so gear up accordingly. The enclosures are a bit old, but still good enough for some nice photos and clear views.Overall it‚Äôs a fun place to spend a few hours with nature and wildlife.

Arignar Anna Zoological Park is a serene and green space perfect for a one-time family visit. The zoo has a good variety of animals, though viewing can be tricky since many enclosures are set at a distance. Navigation inside the park can be a little confusing due to limited signage, so a map or guidance would help. Overall, it‚Äôs a clean, well-kept place worth checking out if you enjoy nature and wildlife

I recently visited the zoo, and it was a wonderful experience. The place is well-maintained with clean surroundings and clearly marked pathways, making it easy to navigate. The variety of animals is impressive ‚Äî from majestic lions and playful monkeys to colorful birds and reptiles. Each enclosure is spacious and designed to resemble the animals‚Äô natural habitat, which shows the effort put into their care and comfort.

The staff were friendly and informative, always ready to answer questions. Educational boards near each enclosure provided useful details about the species, which made the visit not only fun but also very informative.

Facilities like restrooms, food stalls, and seating areas were clean and accessible. It‚Äôs a great spot for families, especially children, as it‚Äôs both entertaining and educational.

Overall, the zoo offers a perfect balance of conservation, education, and recreation. I‚Äôd definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys spending time with nature and wildlife.

Visited the zoo recently and it brought back a lot of childhood memories. Being one of the oldest and largest zoos, it‚Äôs always nostalgic and impressive. The zoo is quite spacious, with a wide variety of animals, making it a great place to spend an entire day.

A few tips for visitors: carry an empty water bottle ‚Äì there are many refill stations available, and it's best to avoid single-use plastic bottles. The entry fee is ‚Çπ200, which feels a bit on the higher side, so better maintenance and organization would be expected at that price.

Overall, it was a great experience. I enjoyed walking around and managed to capture some good pictures of the animals too.

It's not that great. It's very difficult to see wild animals like tigers and lions  because those animals are very far away to see. The distance of the entire park is also so large. But the good thing is there are cycles  available on rent. The cost of the cycle is from Rs.30 to Rs.120 (electric cycles are also available). The entry for Zoo ticket is Rs.200 for adults and Rs.50 for children. Even elephants are also staying long distance. The management should improve a lot.

Wonderful Day Out with Family or Friends!

We spent an entire day here with our family group, and it was a great experience! There's plenty of parking available, though do note that parking is chargeable. You can take a ticket either by scanning the QR code at the entrance or by paying at the cash counter.

Before entering the zoo, there's a strict check NO PLASTIC items are allowed, which is a great initiative for the environment. You‚Äôre allowed to bring food and snacks, but only in steel containers, which is especially helpful if you're visiting with kids or adults who prefer home-packed meals.

Inside, you can choose how you want to explore the place. You can rent a cycle (battery or manual) or simply walk around if you have the stamina and want to take your time. One of the highlights is the Jeep Safari for the lion visit it‚Äôs an AC vehicle and requires a separate ticket.

At the end of the visit, there's a children‚Äôs play area, along with a snacks shop and food court, making it a nice way to wind down after all the walking and exploring.

Overall, it's a well-maintained and family,friendly place perfect for a fullday outing!

I went to this big zoo on the weekend. I got in around 2:30 PM and it took me about three hours to see everything. They had bikes and e-bikes, but the lines were crazy long, so I just walked. They also had electric vehicles, which would be great for older folks. Overall, it was a good time. I thought the ticket lines would be a nightmare, but they had QR codes, so it was easy. Plus, there are restaurants and little shops, so you won't go hungry.

It offers visitors a virtual tour of the night sky and hosts astronomy shows on its specially perforated hemispherical aluminum inner dome. reviews.reviewText:
Visiting the Birla Planetarium and Periyar Science and Technology Centre in Chennai was a great experience. There‚Äôs a lot to see from life-size rocket models like the GSLV and BrahMos to interactive science exhibits. The 360-degree 3D sphere show was definitely a highlight really immersive and well done. I also found the weighing machine that shows your weight on different planets pretty cool.

The human evolution section with displays on early humans and Neanderthals was interesting and there were plenty of exhibits covering space chemistry and physics. The outdoor area had some dinosaur models though a few could use some maintenance. There were also some defense and technology exhibits adding to the variety. I noticed another 3D show but I didn‚Äôt have time to check it out.

Overall it‚Äôs a great place for anyone interested in space and science. Definitely worth a visit especially for students and families

It was awesome visiting this place with the kids!  Totally recommend it.  Grab the combo ticket and check out the three amazing shows.

Adult tickets are ‚Çπ60 and kids' tickets are ‚Çπ30 for the planetarium, science center, and 3D show package.  "Science on Sphere" is ‚Çπ20 for adults and ‚Çπ10 for kids.

The Planetarium can show all kinds of celestial movements.  They use special projectors to make the astronomical stuff look incredible on the dome.

Popular exhibits include the Solar System, stars, seasons, comets, and the moon landing.  There's also a cool DRDO pavilion.

The "Dawn of the Space Age" show is a mind-blowing Mirrordome+ experience ‚Äì super realistic space travel visuals.

Children's park is free of charges. For planetarium charges above 12 years of Rs. 80 and below 12 years Rs.40. Car parking Rs. 20.
3D show is amusing and the planetarium gives good knowledge about the universe too the children.
Nearly maintained. Children can spend hours here.

Birla Planetarium's ability to bring the night sky to life with its virtual tours and astronomy shows,

This place is a must visit for kids at least in their lifetime.

Virtual Tours : Explore the night sky with virtual tours that simulate astronomical phenomena

Astronomy Shows : Engage with 35 different audio-visual programs explaining cosmic phenomena, shown in English and Tamil

Science Exhibits : Discover over 500 exhibits across eight galleries, covering topics like life science, electronics, and energy

3D Science Shows : Enjoy immersive 3D experiences, including shows on dinosaurs and scientific concepts

Science Park : Explore outdoor exhibitions on scientific principles, including solar energy and wind energy.

Entry Fee: ‚Çπ35 for adults,
‚Çπ20 for children below 12 years for the planetarium;
‚Çπ25 per person for 3D shows
Bike parking ‚Çπ5

Best to buy ‚Çπ100 combo for all activities

Near by Location: Gandhi Mandapam Road

Excellent place to visit in the heart of the city specially along with kids. Very informative.

3d show, spherical show, evolution garden were great. Price is very decent.

Birla Planetarium is located right in the heart of the city. It‚Äôs a quiet place with plenty of parking available in front. The ticket prices are very reasonable ‚Äì **INR 100 for adults and INR 50 for children** covers the entire package (Planetarium show, entry, 3D show, and Sphere show). There‚Äôs also an option to buy a **basic INR 35 ticket** for only the Planetarium show.

The campus is not very large, so walking inside is easy. At the entrance, you‚Äôre greeted by an **old fighter jet (HAL HF-24 Marut)**, an **old steam locomotive**, and a **model of the GSLV rocket**. There‚Äôs also an **evolution park (Dinosaur World)**, but unfortunately, like the science and industrial play areas for kids, it isn‚Äôt well maintained.

The **real highlight is inside** ‚Äì the Planetarium and the Science Exhibition Centre. Clean washrooms are available outside, and there are gift, souvenir, and toy shops inside. Food options are limited to a small snack counter selling tea, coffee, and light snacks, so it‚Äôs best to carry your own lunch if you plan to spend the full 5‚Äì6 hours here. Do note that food and water bottles are not allowed inside the Planetarium show, but they can be deposited at the front desk.

**Science & Exhibition Centre:**

* **Ground Floor:**

* DRDO Gallery (models of tanks, battle equipment, and Tejas aircraft)
* Hall of Nuclear Power (detailed displays on nuclear power generation)
* 3D Show (10-minute dinosaur world movie with 3D glasses ‚Äì very exciting for kids)

* **First Floor:**

* Oceans Gallery
* Mirror House (fun for kids with mirror illusions)
* Indian Space Gallery (models, information on ISRO projects, and a live quiz show)
* Ramanujan Mathematics Gallery (interactive experiments)
* Heart Museum (hearts of different animals preserved in jars)
* Science on a Sphere (visual science show on a spherical display)

**Planetarium Show:**
The absolute **star attraction** ‚Äì a 20-minute immersive journey through space, stars, the Sun, Moon, and other planets. Truly fascinating, especially for children.

‚ú® **Overall:** Birla Planetarium is highly educational and an excellent place for kids interested in science, space, and technology. While the outdoor exhibits and some galleries could use better maintenance, the Planetarium and Science Centre make the visit absolutely worthwhile.

Great experience ! Very informative.  kids / students will love this place! Myst visit place in Chennai. They also have good washroom facilities , food stalls , kids play area. Ample parking . Like a very good place to spend the whole day .
The park was pretty neat and clean. Planetarium was really good and do was the 3d show and science on a sphere. The shop and galleries were a hit. Only negative was the rusted and broken projects.

This temple is located near Thiruvanmiyur Bus Terminus and it's a walkable distance from the ECR Bus stop in Thiruvanmiyur.

It's one of the famous temples in Chennai which is dedicated to Lord Shiva and he is represented as Marundeeswarar. You will feel peace when you spend here..

After visiting the temple, you can visit Thiruvanmiyur beach which is 2km from the temple and you can relax and feel a fresh mind and the day will be more satisfying..

Marundeeswarar Temple is a temple dedicated to Hindu deity Shiva, located in Thiruvanmiyur, Chennai adjacent to the beach of Bay of Bengal.
Moolavar: Marundeeswarar
Amman: Tiripurasundari.

Paadal Petra Sthalams where two of the most revered Nayanars Appar and Tirugnana Sambandar

The temple has two seven-tiered gateway towers, a huge tank east side
The Marundeeswarar temple has been a place of curative worship for people with diseases.

Marundeeswarar is known so because he imparted sage Agastya on curative properties of various herbs and plants.Since then the Marundeeswarar temple has been a place of worship for people with diseases and various problems with their health.It is said that sage Valmiki, who wrote Ramayana, worshiped Shiva in the temple.Since Valmiki was blessed here, the place was to be known as Thiruvalmikiyur, which is pronounced as 'Thiruvanmikiyur' in Tamil, the name gradually changed to Thiruvanmiyur. There is a place present in Thiruvanmiyur called Valmiki Nagar in his honour.

Arulmigu Marundeeswarar Temple, Thiruvanmiyur (Chennai)
Visited this majestic Shiva temple and felt completely rejuvenated by its serene and healing atmosphere.

Highlights & History

The temple is an ancient Paadal Petra Sthalam, praised by Saivite saints Appar and Sambandar in the 7th century  .

Originally built during the Pallava era and expanded by Chola and Vijayanagara rulers, its current structure dates back over 1,000 years  .

Known as ‚ÄúMarundeeswarar‚Äù (Lord of Medicines), legend says Shiva taught sage Agastya the healing secrets of herbs here  . Devotees still seek blessings for health.

Sage Valmiki and other saints like Bharadwaja, Markandeya, and even the celestial Kamadhenu cow are all connected to this temple‚Äôs lore  .

Architecture & Deity

The temple sits on about 1 acre, with two grand seven-tiered gopurams on East Coast Road and West Tank Street  .

Inside, a large mandapam with 36 intricately carved pillars houses the serene Somaskanda form of Shiva, alongside shrines for Tripurasundari (Parvati), Murugan, Ganesha, Dakshinamurthy, and others  .

The self-manifested (swayambhu) Shiva Linga, called Palvannanathar, stands facing west ‚Äî a rarity among Shiva temples  .

Visitor Experience

The temple exudes a calm, spiritual energy. Devotees come here seeking healing and peace, often taking ritual dips in its sacred tank  .

It hosts six daily rituals and twelve annual festivals, including Panguni Brahmotsavam and Maha Shivaratri  .

After a recent ‚Çπ75 lakh renovation (2020 Kumbhabhishekam), the temple is beautifully maintained and vibrant  .

In summary, the Marundeeswarar Temple is far more than a historic structure ‚Äî it feels like a living sanctuary of spiritual healing and timeless devotion. A definitive must-visit on Chennai‚Äôs temple trail.

A unique feature of the temple is the sacred tree (Sthala Vriksham) under which Lord Shiva is believed to have given darshan. The space around the tree feels calm and spiritually powerful ‚Äî a perfect spot to sit peacefully for a few minutes.

The temple is spacious, well-maintained, and offers a serene experience, especially on weekdays. It's a great place to escape from the hustle of the city while still being in the heart of Chennai.

Note: There are a few stray dogs outside the temple premises. They usually stay around the entrance and can be aggressive at times ‚Äî it's best to stay cautious and avoid approaching them.

A must-visit for anyone seeking a spiritually enriching experience in Chennai.

Parking of vechile is available with a cost of 50

Such a beautiful temple the only challenge was to park your car. It‚Äôs on the main road and you have to keep your car on running road. I was surprised local person was not aware of the temple as the map location was slightly incorrect. But had a good experience. I went to weekend and it was crowded.

This massive Hindu deity Shiva temple situated in Tiruvanmayur offers the best sense of spiritual realisation. The presiding lord Marundheeshwarar is considered to have known for imparting  sage Agastya with curative properties of various herbs and plants.  Since then the temple has been a place of worship for people with diseases and various problems with their health, purely a belief that is followed by masses.

The temple is believed to have partial feature of Pallava dynasty and partially with Chola art.

One of the oldest temples of South India estimated to be 1300 years old, the temple complex is maintained neat and clean.  Houses many other sannadhis of god/goddess, with a large temple pond and an ancient tree that has significance.  There are few olden days stone carvings kept in the inner circumference of the temple.  Dont miss from seeing them...they can tell you how old the structure is. A must visit temple in Chennai.

Clicking pictures of deities is prohibited.
Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva known for its spiritual and healing power. Area is huge and well maintained. Mural paintings on the walls of rooftop is amazing.

Visiting Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple was a very peaceful and divine experience for me. The calm atmosphere inside the temple instantly made me feel blessed and at ease. I was truly amazed by the beautiful architecture and the spiritual energy of the place. I left with a sense of positivity and inner peace, and I would love to visit again.

Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple is an ancient and sacred temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, worshipped here as Marundheeshvarar ‚Äì the God of Medicine. It is believed that Sage Valmiki and many saints worshipped here, and that prayers offered at this temple bring relief from illness and promote good health.

The temple has a very traditional and serene atmosphere, with beautiful architecture and carvings that reflect the Chola period. The main deity, Lord Shiva in the form of Marundheeshvarar, along with Goddess Tripurasundari, radiates immense divinity. The temple is also associated with healing powers, making it spiritually unique.

Daily poojas and abhishekams are performed with devotion, and festivals such as Shivaratri, Pradosham, and Navaratri are celebrated in a grand manner. The temple premises are clean, well maintained, and the priests are helpful in guiding devotees.

Visiting Arulmigu Marundheeshvarar Temple is not just a spiritual experience but also a journey into history, culture, and divine healing. It is truly a must-visit temple for devotees of Lord Shiva and for anyone seeking peace, health, and blessings. üôè‚ú®

Arulmigu Vadapalani Murugan Temple (Chennai) is devotion with momentum‚Äînadaswaram in the air, steady darshan lines, and the towering gopuram welcoming you from a distance. The sanctum feels powerful and unhurried; priests are courteous and guide first-timers through simple offerings. The campus is clean, prasadam counters run smoothly (pongal/laddu are worth it), and there‚Äôs shade to sit for a few quiet minutes even on busy days. It‚Äôs also a popular wedding temple, so you may catch a mandapam buzzing with ceremonies.

Good to know: Tuesdays, Fridays, Kanda Sashti, and Thai Poosam draw big crowds‚Äîcome early morning or late evening. Footwear counters are organized; photography is fine in outer prakarams (not inside the sanctum). Parking is tight around Arcot Road‚ÄîVadapalani Metro station is the easiest way in. Dress modestly and carry small change/UPI for archana tickets and prasadam.

Tip: If you prefer a quicker darshan, ask at the counter for the special-entry line.
Secret tip: Arrive just before opening time‚Äîthe first deeparadhanai (‚Äúsuprabhatham‚Äù vibe) is the calmest, most beautiful moment, with the Vel lit by lamps and hardly any crowd.

I visited this temple around 10:30 AM on a Thursday, and it was quite busy, which shows how much devotion people here have. Just before the main entrance, I noticed a small chapel stand, open for free to visitors. Inside the temple, there are multiple idols of different gods‚Äîit‚Äôs not dedicated to just one deity. The sculptures and architecture are truly impressive, reflecting the temple‚Äôs rich heritage, as it is said to have been constructed around the 8th century.

I personally prefer old temples, and this one stands out with its intricate carvings and spiritual atmosphere. There is also a temple pond within the premises, which I couldn‚Äôt visit this time, but it adds to the traditional charm.

For anyone interested in experiencing ancient temples with great sculptures and strong cultural significance, this temple is a must-visit. Accessibility is also convenient, as the Vadapalani Metro Station is nearby, making it easy for commuters.

It is one of the oldest temples in Chennai. Apart from Lord muruga, the temple has other worships of Hanuman, Ganesha, Siva and others. We visited on a weekend and it was bit crowded. We waited for 20 minutes. Parking facility is available and you have to pay 20 rupees per car. It is not properly maintained, however there is some facility in a ground near to temple. Road to the temple is very narrow. It is recommended to go with Two wheeler.

‚ú® Vadapalani Murugan Kovil ‚ú®
I had the chance to visit this beautiful temple in the heart of the city to witness a family friend‚Äôs wedding. We were in Pillar 1 Hall, and it was such a great experience.

This was actually my first visit about a year ago, and the memories from that day are still so special. Truly a wonderful place filled with divine energy and beautiful moments. üôèüí´

As a traveller, visiting Vadapalani Murugan Temple was a divine and memorable experience. placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Dakshina Chitra Heritage Museum in Chennai offers a comprehensive experience of South Indian culture, traditions, and artworks. The museum features 18 historical houses and showcases art, crafts, music, and dance forms from four major South Indian states. Visitors can explore exhibits on pre-colonial clothing, farming practices, and architecture. Additionally, the museum hosts performances and has stalls selling traditional jewelry, fashion items, and souvenirs.
placeMetadata.address: State Highway 49, Muthukadu, Tamil Nadu 603112, India

reviews.reviewText: DakshinaChitra Heritage Museum is a must-visit place in Chennai to experience South Indian culture, art, and architecture. The traditional houses from different states are beautifully preserved and give you a glimpse of history and heritage. There are live crafts, art workshops, and cultural performances that make the visit even more engaging. The campus is well maintained, peaceful, and spacious ‚Äî perfect for families, students, and anyone interested in culture. A truly enriching and memorable experience.

In today's electronic age, children are growing up with limited understanding of their roots and a diminished appreciation for what they possess. This place offers a wonderful opportunity to visit and impart knowledge of our heritage. They have meticulously recreated various aspects of South Indian cultures and related replicas, while also actively promoting historical arts and handicrafts. I strongly recommend that families, especially those seeking to instill values in their children, consider a day outing here. It's a commendable initiative supported by excellent companies.

Great place. Presents a slice of South India. Very well maintained. Some shows, puppetry on the weekends, for instance available. Great place to click some pictures: several South Indian style houses, art exhibits, sculptures and artifacts. Favours the folk, and the Tamil. Ideologically left leaning. Need at half a day to have a meaningful visit.

Bags are not allowed inside. Amenities available. Shops sell you stuff, beautiful stuff, but expensive. No exclusively vegetarian eatery inside.

Must visit if you are in and around Chennai.

It‚Äôs really a worth visiting place when in Chennai‚Ä¶ If you have even a little interest in knowing about South Indian heritage and particularly about traditional houses in various regions..
A very well maintained premises with lots of trees and nicely paved walking path.. There are some nice small handicrafts and souvenir shops to buy from.
There‚Äôs also a small canteen for tea/coffee/snacks and a full fledged restaurant that offers South Indian veg/non meals at very reasonable rates and offers good taste.

Has always been a favorite of mine to spend a quiet weekend. Brought some out-of-town visitors this time, and they loved the heritage museum set up with interesting tidbits, authentic houses, folk dance performances and shopping. Would be a great idea to add food that is traditional and authentic to each of the southern states as small eateries or restaurants.

A cultural heritage on the southern India and lots of activities for the children to explore the creativity thinking. A timely shows on each places of real character which will be make us to enjoyment and fun. Really worthy and takes minimum 5-6 hrs to explore..

Everything about the museum is good. You‚Äôll need an entire day to truly explore and learn from it. It‚Äôs a wonderful experience not only for kids but also for builders, architects, or even anyone dreaming of constructing their own home.

So why only 3 stars? Mainly because of the confusing layout and lack of proper guidance. Some areas are not well maintained‚Äîcertain buildings and rooms are closed without explanation, while others are being used for storage. Although I was given a pamphlet with a map, it was hardly useful.

From the entrance to the exit, there should at least be clear milestones or directional boards. For example: ‚ÄúStart here ‚Üí Next visit Tamil Nadu House ‚Üí Exit this way. To visit Kerala House, follow this route,‚Äù etc. Without proper instructions, it‚Äôs very difficult to fully enjoy and experience the cultural richness and diversity showcased in the museum.

I visited Dhakana Chitra Heritage Museum with my family last weekend, and it was one of the most enjoyable and enriching day trips we‚Äôve had in a long time. This place is more than just a museum ‚Äî it‚Äôs a well-planned heritage village that combines cultural learning with a comfortable, family-friendly environment. I‚Äôll share my experience in detail so that it helps anyone planning a visit.

‚è∞ Timings & Entry
The museum is open from morning till evening (usually around 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM), and I recommend arriving as early as possible. We reached around 10:30 AM, which was perfect because the place was less crowded, the weather was cooler, and we could take our time exploring without rushing. The ticket counter staff were friendly and explained the map of the place so we could plan our route. They also mentioned the timings for any live demonstrations happening that day.

üßπ Cleanliness & Maintenance
One of the first things I noticed was how incredibly clean and well-maintained the entire place is. The pathways are swept, there‚Äôs no litter anywhere, and the gardens are beautifully trimmed. Even the restrooms ‚Äî something I‚Äôm always cautious about when visiting public places ‚Äî were spotless, with running water, soap, and hand-drying facilities. The traditional houses and displays are also well-kept, with no dust or neglect, which really adds to the pleasant experience.

üç¥ Food & Refreshments
There‚Äôs a small but well-run food court area inside the museum grounds. The menu is simple, offering local South Indian snacks like dosa, idli, vada, and upma, along with fresh juices, coffee, and tea. Prices are reasonable, and the food tastes fresh and homely. We had a late breakfast of masala dosa and filter coffee, and it was delicious. For lunch, there‚Äôs a traditional thali option that gives you an authentic taste of local cuisine. There are also cold drinks, bottled water, and ice creams available, which is great if you‚Äôre visiting with kids. The seating area is shaded, clean, and surrounded by greenery, so it‚Äôs relaxing to take a break here.

Arrive early to avoid the afternoon heat and crowds.

Wear comfortable shoes because there‚Äôs a lot of walking.

Keep a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen handy.

Carry some cash if you want to buy directly from artisans (though the main food court accepts digital payments).

Plan to spend at least 3 hours here ‚Äî more if you have kids who want to explore every corner.

üèõ Museum Layout & Attractions
The museum is designed like a small village, with different sections showcasing heritage from various parts of India. Each house or structure you enter has information boards in English and regional languages, explaining its history and purpose. This makes it easy for both adults and older children to understand and appreciate what they‚Äôre seeing

üé≠ Cultural Performances & Seasonal Events
Depending on when you visit, there may be live folk dance or music performances. We were lucky to catch a small folk dance performance in the afternoon, and it really added to the atmosphere. During festival seasons, the museum often has special events, craft fairs, and workshops for kids, so it‚Äôs worth checking their calendar before you go.

üå≥ Atmosphere & Comfort
The entire place has a very peaceful, relaxing atmosphere. Even though there‚Äôs a lot to see, it doesn‚Äôt feel rushed or crowded. The shaded walkways, occasional benches, and water refill stations make it easy to take breaks. There are plenty of trees and open spaces, so it‚Äôs never stuffy.

If you‚Äôre into photography, the museum is a paradise ‚Äî every corner is photogenic, from the colorful doors to the hand-painted walls and traditional artefacts

üõç Shopping for Souvenirs
Near the exit, there‚Äôs a gift shop selling authentic handicrafts, postcards, and handmade toys. Prices are fair, and the quality is much better than what you‚Äôd find in typical tourist markets. We picked up a couple of hand-painted wooden keychains and a small terracotta pot ‚Äî perfect as reminders of our visit

This marshmallow-pink pavilion served as a meditation space for the renowned monk during his stay in 1897. Located on Marina Beach Road in Chennai, it holds significance as one of the historical places in the city. placeMetadata.address: VIVEKANANDA HOUSE, Kamaraj Salai, Marina Beach Road, Triplicane, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600005, India

reviews.reviewText: Vivekananda House is a must-visit heritage site in Chennai, rich with history and spiritual significance. The place beautifully preserves the legacy of Swami Vivekananda and offers a peaceful, inspiring atmosphere. The exhibits are well-organized and informative, showcasing his life, teachings, and his historic stay here. The meditation room is especially calming, perfect for quiet reflection. Located right by the Marina Beach, it‚Äôs a great spot for both tourists and locals who are interested in culture and philosophy. Highly recommended!

I recently visited Vivekananda House and had an inspiring experience. The place is well-maintained and beautifully showcases the life and teachings of Swami Vivekananda. One of the highlights of my visit was the 4D VR show, which took us through Swami Vivekananda's powerful and spiritual journey in a truly immersive way.

The visuals, sound, and storytelling were amazing‚Äîit felt like I was walking alongside him through different phases of his life, especially his journey to the West and his speech at the Parliament of Religions in Chicago. It gave me a deeper understanding of his vision, thoughts, and contribution to Indian philosophy.

Overall, it's a must-visit place for anyone interested in history, spirituality, or just looking for inspiration. I left the place feeling motivated and proud of our rich cultural heritage.

Everything was excellent‚ú®üòÅ
1. Ambiance
2. 4D Movie with excellent Bass and effects
3. Virtual Reality experience was top notch
4. Photo with Swami Vivekananda felt special
5. Meditation room was divine
6. AC was very good

All comes with a very affordable price of ‚Çπ 50/-

If you are in Chennai a must watch place for all. Just spend 1 hour and give it a tryü§©üëçüí´‚ú®

Situated opposite to the Marina Beach. This is like a museum of Swami Vivekananda, where you can see the photos with the timelines of his life.

Very neatly maintained. There are are couple of theatres inside the museum where his Chicago speech, his early life are been portrayed. It will take some time in order to visit the museum. There is also a mediation hall where you can sit and meditate which is described as the place where he used to meditate when he came to Chennai.

They do have a bookstore where they sell his books. The ticket charges ‚Çπ50 per head. They will also take a photo free of cost and can be downloaded from the link they provide.

Fabulous experience. INR 50 per head for the entire activity. Excellent conduct by staff. In this cost you will get a walk around,3D,VR presentations + meditation time. This is all about swami vivekananda teachings,history,his speech at America. Parking is free. Must visit if you are near to marina beach. Thank me later. No other hidden fees

It‚Äôs a great place with high spiritual vibes.
There is a Meditation room, a VR room where you can see Swami Vivekananda‚Äôs story till he went to Chicago.
There is a 3D theatre which shows the Swami Vivekananda‚Äôs speech at world religious parliament in Chicago.
You can feel Swamiji‚Äôs aura present in this room when you meditate.
The entry ticket is only 50‚Çπ, which I feel is very nominal.
Outside there is a book stall also they run few yoga and spiritual courses as well.
You can see the Marina beach from the top floor. It has got a beautiful view.
Had a great experience!
I would highly recommend visiting this place.

Vivekananda House ‚Äì Marina, Chennai

For me, Vivekananda House has always been a landmark of Marina Beach. I‚Äôve been seeing this place from outside for more than 25 years, since my childhood, as it is close to my grandfather‚Äôs house. Whenever I go across Marina, this pink building always stands out and reminds me of its cultural and historical significance.

Though many people visit inside for school trips, exhibitions, or spiritual visits to learn about Swami Vivekananda and experience peace, the outside itself has a charm. Recently, opposite Vivekananda House, they have started putting up a big screen for open-air Tamil movie screenings, where the crowd sits together to watch evergreen films. The atmosphere becomes lively, with nearby stalls selling hot crispy bhajjis, ice creams, seafood like fish and prawn, fried rice, sodas, and popcorn ‚Äì giving a true Chennai beachside vibe.

This place beautifully balances heritage and modern leisure ‚Äì inside for culture and spirituality, and outside for entertainment and food. Truly, Vivekananda House is not just a building but a symbol of Marina itself.

Swami Vivekananda stayed in the building when he visited Chennai in 1897, and it was later renamed in his honor.
The place where swami stayed is today converted as a meditation hall, which is very calm and pleasant

Paintings are too good üòä

reviews.reviewText: Super nice park. If you go in the weekends it might be a little crowded but it is super huge. Boating and other fun activities are available at a minimal cost. I liked watching the ducks while walking around the lake. Parking space for 2 wheelers and cars is good enough

A wonderful Place to visit with family, friends and kids. A calm, serene and clean space in the city is such a welcome. We couldn‚Äôt goto the boating since we went at 8 AM but I‚Äôm sure it would have been fun! The flowers and scenery were amazing.

Not recommending that much. I can assure you will not enjoy the place and can choose other park options. I went this Sunday first of all I parked my car outside of the parking zone still the parking person forcefully took parking charges. On entering I paid 25/- ticket but inside nothing I saw just a simple small lake and few trees.  Very small and half of the portion of the park is closed and not accessible from the public. It‚Äôs only for daily walkers. The security guards were weird and was giving weird look making me uncomfortable. On asking anything they were very rude. Overall below average experience.

We went to Chetpet Ecopark on a weekend evening with the kids and we had a good time there.

Located in the middle of busy area the Ecopark was so well maintained. I was surprised to see such a natural beauty in the middle of the busy city. There was an entrance ticket 24 rs for adults and 10 rs for kids and parking ticket based on the number of hours.

We walked around the beautiful lake during the sunset, the air there was so fresh. There were snacks joint in between near to kids play area where there were snacks and icecream available.

There is a separate walking trail available only for members who walk on a regular basis and not open for others.

We had a very peaceful walk and there was boating also available but as it was dark we did not try it. After the walk we ended up at a place where the carnival was happening and there was a host conducting games for families.. There was some paid games available at that place for kids . It was good to see families enjoying their time and adults playing some games..

Overall we had a very good time in the  Really appreciate the government for making that lake as a beautiful Eco park where people can go and en6the beautiful nature.

Chetpet Eco Park is a lovely green space with a beautiful lake offering boating and fishing (with membership and restricted timings). The small aquarium had limited fish varieties, with many empty tanks. The outdoor seating area is convenient, and the food outlet has moderate prices but average taste. It's a good spot for a casual visit, fulfilling cravings, and enjoying nature, but not exceptional in any particular aspect.

Beautiful place in the heart of the city!
I had a great evening here with my friend. There‚Äôs a ‚Çπ25 entrance fee for adults, which is totally worth it. Some specific attractions like boating, gaming, and the fish aquarium require separate tickets. Overall, a lovely spot to relax and enjoy.
Well maintained and clean ecopark, boat ride, aquarium are nice. Kids play area can be improved
Good calm place to relax and enjoy with your friends and family. Rating 4 out of 5 only because they do not take boat riding a full round around the lake. Can improve food stall

placeMetadata.name: Madras War Cemetery

sources.snippet: The Madras War Memorial of Chennai is built in dedication to the martyrs of World War II. It is made of white marble and carved beautifully. The names of all those soldiers who lost their lives in the war have been carved on the structure of this memorial. There are gardens surrounding the building where you can stroll, or visit the Stone of Remembrance.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places To Visit In Chennai (Madras) (2025)

sources.snippet: Pay your respects at the tranquil Madras War Cemetery, which houses a memorial stone in honour of the 1000 people who sacrificed their lives in the Great War and the remains of almost 855 martyrs from the Second World War. It is one of the most unique places to visit in Chennai. The nearest railway station is Chennai Central Railway Station.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: 8 km from city center 18 out of 90 Places To Visit in Chennai. The Madras War Cemetery houses the last remains of around 855 martyrs who laid down their precious lives at the battlefronts in the devastating Second World War and also a Memorial stone for 1000 more who died fighting in the Great War before that.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Madras War Cemetery, established by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, is a solemn site dedicated to honoring the fallen soldiers of East and South India from World War II. Similar to other Commonwealth cemeteries like Singapore's Kranji Cemetery, it provides a peaceful sanctuary despite its location alongside a bustling road. The well-maintained grounds and the Madras 1914-1918 War Memorial at the back stand as poignant reminders of sacrifice and valor.

This place gave a European vibe with flowers and greenery. It‚Äôs a great place to spend some quality time. Even though it‚Äôs in a busy road side, the place gives a great sense of calmness and peace. It‚Äôs a must visit spot.

Such a nice place to take photographs ‚Ä¶. Fully cleaned ‚Ä¶. Neat and Tiny ‚Ä¶. Peaceful place ‚Ä¶. Full and Fully situated with green Grass ‚Ä¶. It can cover everyone‚Äôs eyes ‚Ä¶. One of the Respectable place for war soldiers ‚Ä¶. There is nothing to watch here ‚Ä¶. You can just visit here to take photos ‚Ä¶.

It's almost so serene and peaceful it's literally on the sides of the road and yet once you enter it becomes so quite and just so soothing! It's a beautiful place and really well maintained. You can go there Nd sit for a long time and not notice the traffic noises! Definitely quite a wonderful place and must visit on any low days you have. Just get in there sit and it will soothe you!

reviews.reviewText:
One of the best theme parks in Chennai.
Awesome rides with a well organized water park. Food and eateries are decent, skill games, and fancy stores are also around. My favorite was the roller coaster, the RANGER and adult slides in the water park. Awesome experience.

Good place to hangout with kids, family, and friends. Better to avoid during weekends as it will be very crowded with school children coming here for excursion trips and would have to wait a for a long time in queue to attend each and every rides. Water rides are amazing and much more relaxing after the lunch.

If you are lucky to get tickets during any sale like the Black Friday sale, it's worth the amount.

Reducing one star because of the expensive items inside the theme park. A tin of soft drink costing at ‚Çπ70 and normal water bottle at ‚Çπ30, which ideally is just ‚Çπ20 outside.

Good place to hang out with friends and families.

Sometimes offers might be there in their site so check it once before going directly to ticket counter for buying tickets.

They have normal ticket (need to wait if crowded) and priority pass ticket (no waiting in queue)

Plenty of parking spaces available but it is 200m away from entrance.
For car -100rs and bike it‚Äôs 50rs as parking fee.

Good adventurous rides are available like ranger, roller coaster, water coaster, etc.

Swimming pool, wave pool, waterfall, rain dance floor are available to have fun.

Wave pool is small when compared with other theme park.

If you are going with girl child or girls then be safe since everyone is enjoying in pool. I don‚Äôt think, there is a separate pool for kids & women.

By evening time there will be a dance floor lightening with few dancers and anyone can go and dance with them if you want.

This place is on the ECR and on the main road. People coming from north Chennai, should be starting early. I advice people to be here @10 am sharp to start early and enjoy all the rides. That too on weekends it is highly crowded and you have to wait at least 30 mins for each ride. Area of this place is not huge to cover it as like queensland. All rides are enjoyable with friends and family. Canteen is available here, no outside foods are allowed here. Prices of food is ok. Quality and quantity also ok. Few rides are really mind blowing and thrilling experience. Water games are always best in MGM. So start early and enjoy all the games till the evening. Auto or cab from here to return home may be very costly. So plan it accordingly.

It was good place. They have a good number of rides, but they are hell crowded. Please keep something to cover yourself from scorching heat. They have 2-3 diners. One of them is pure veg. They have a water park also, which gets open around 2-5 only. There are water rides for kids and adults. They have a rain dance area.  They have bucket splashes at 2 places. When I went, it was hell crowded. There is boating also. You can see the calm beach from the top of the rides amidst the palm trees. It feels like scenery.

Cost of ticket for adult - 1250‚Çπ
For child - 825‚Çπ
Car parking is the opposite side of the- 100‚Çπ for car
Since it was last few days before the school start, we decided to go have some fun. It was not much crowded. Didn‚Äôt wait in queue to sit on any ride. All ride were functional and we were able to go multiple times in each ride. Kids enjoyed too since it was their first time.
Water park was also wonderful. Wave poll, rain dance and kids area in the pool were too much fun. Lockers are available there to keep your stuffs and enter the pool.

Food and water are available inside to purchase. Food is not as expensive as I expected, 80‚Çπ for veg fried rice, 40‚Çπ for orange juice etc. It was ok.

It definitely is not worth the price at all. There are very few rides that an adult would enjoy for the price we pay. If you have been to Wonderla, this is ten times a downgrade for the high price of a ticket. In terms of dry rides, Queensland is better and cheaper. And don't even ask me about water rides; only one was functional when I went. You can definitely have fun if you go as a gang, but I would personally save up some money and time and visit Wonderla for a fulfilling adventure park fun time with friends.

It's a great experience with all the thrill rides as well as water rides..
We go with corporate booking and the team is very very helpful in all manners with full support to conduct events well ..,
Buffet lunch from Gem restaurant also awesome in taste and good coordination as well
