reviews.reviewText:
My Favourite spot in Chennai.
Morning sunrise view is an Eye Catchy.

Besant Nagar Beach, also known as Edward Elliot's Beach is one of the most popular and serene beaches in Chennai, Tamil Nadu. Located in the upscale neighborhood of Besant Nagar, this beach is a favorite spot for locals and tourists looking for a peaceful seaside experience.

Highlights

Scenic Beauty: A clean and less crowded alternative to Marina Beach, offering beautiful sunrise and sunset views.

Restaurants & Cafes: The area around the beach is home to many famous eateries like Murugan Idli Shop, Jonah‚Äôs Bistro, and Mash Resto Caf√©.

The nearby Ashtalakshmi Temple and Velankanni Church attract visitors for spiritual experiences.

A great place for morning or evening walks, jogging, or just relaxing by the sea.

Besant Nagar Beach offers a refreshing coastal escape with beautiful sunsets, clean sands, spiritual landmarks, and vibrant street food‚Äîin a much calmer setting than busy city beaches. However, be mindful of rising vendor clutter and occasional sanitation concerns. Overall, it‚Äôs a top choice for a relaxed day out, especially in the mornings or evenings.

Best experience you can get here. We went on a weekday and it‚Äôs more quieter than marina beach during night. Nice walking path in the beach and it‚Äôs clean. There is also skating park for kids.

The shops are clean and as it‚Äôs weekday not all shops opened. Overall a must visit beach in Chennai. Don‚Äôt miss this even if u miss Marina beach.

Besant Nagar Beach is a wonderful spot to visit. While the beachfront is relatively small, the area is moderately clean and well-maintained. It boasts a wide range of food options, from local street vendors to popular multi-level restaurant chains, offering a variety of cuisines to enjoy.

Besant Nagar Beach is a wonderful spot to visit and truly a delightful experience. The beach is clean, the atmosphere is calm, and the streets nearby are filled with amazing street food that adds to the charm. The park area with its various rides is also worth exploring and makes the visit even more enjoyable. The only drawback is the presence of persistent beggars and vendors, which can be bothersome, so it‚Äôs good to stay cautious. Other than that, Besant Nagar Beach is definitely a must-visit destination in Chennai.

Besant Nagar Beach, also known as Bessie Beach, is hands down one of my favorite places in Chennai. I‚Äôve been visiting it regularly ‚Äì both early in the mornings and late at night, and each visit has something special to offer.

üåÖ Sunrise at the beach is a serene and beautiful experience. The soft golden light, the gentle sound of waves, and the cool breeze instantly lift your mood. It‚Äôs the perfect time to go for a peaceful walk or just sit by the shore and soak in the calmness before the city wakes up.

üåá Sunset, on the other hand, brings its own charm. The sky turns into a canvas of oranges and pinks, and the atmosphere becomes livelier with people strolling, kids playing, and street food vendors lighting up the beachside. There‚Äôs something so refreshing and calming about the place, no matter what time of day it is. The moment you step onto the sand, you feel a sense of peace and lightness that only the sea can bring.

üéâ One of the exciting things about Bessie is that they screen IPL matches on big screens during the season! It adds a vibrant community vibe, with people cheering, relaxing with friends and family, and enjoying snacks while watching the game in the open air with the sea breeze around.

Whether you‚Äôre looking for quiet reflection during sunrise, chilling with friends in the evening, or even just grabbing a bite from the food stalls, Besant Nagar Beach never disappoints. It‚Äôs clean, lively, and safe, and has become a sort of personal escape zone for me within the city.

Highly recommended for anyone visiting Chennai or even locals who haven‚Äôt made this part of their regular routine yet!

Watching the sunrise at Besant Nagar Beach is truly magical. The first light of the day slowly coloring the sky, the gentle sound of the waves, and the cool morning breeze create a peaceful and refreshing start to the day. The view is simply amazing ‚Äî worth waking up early for! A perfect spot for nature lovers and anyone looking to recharge their mind and soul.

Basant Nagar Beach is one of those places where the city‚Äôs chaos fades away, replaced by the calming rhythm of the waves. Whether you visit at dawn, when the sky blushes softly, or in the evening under the moonlit glow, the place feels magical. The waves are lively but soothing, and the breeze carries that unmistakable salty freshness.

There‚Äôs a lively stretch near the shore with small stalls, local snacks, and the hum of people enjoying themselves, yet you can always find quieter corners to just sit and watch the ocean. The beach is perfect for long walks, photography, or simply letting time slow down while the waves kiss your feet.

If you‚Äôre in Chennai, Basant Nagar Beach isn‚Äôt just a spot‚Äîit‚Äôs an experience. üåä‚ú®

reviews.reviewText:
I would say it was a magical experience at Rina‚Äôs venue for our daughter‚Äôs wedding on 28.6.2024. Rina Madam, Nachi, Vijay, Leela, and their team of hair-makers, decorators, organisers gave us a warm welcome whenever met for discussions planning the wedding.

We couldn‚Äôt have asked for more for our daughter‚Äôs wedding. It was an ideal place surrounded by nature, in a beautifully decorated traditional mutham- sanctom, lilly pond, surrounded by trees and artworks representing the cultural values. Our family felt extremely joyful and grateful for the arrangements by Rina‚Äôs team, bringing life to the magical dream wedding.

A perfect spot for a traditional Hindu Brahmin wedding.
We laid the dots of our expectations and saw an incredible kolam( rangoli) transformation on the day. It was heavenly.
We said what colours, patterns  and themes for decorations and garlands. We were all  really impressed by the ambience. A feast for our eyes‚ú®‚≠êÔ∏è
Day 1 Vradham, janavasam, Nithchayadartham and Reception. We didnt feel any stress as it was organised so well by Rina‚Äôs team including DJ/ sound system.

The ISKON temple next door, the beautifully decorated Red Rolls Royce for Janavasam, the electrifying drummer all along bringing out best dance movements and joyful.
The patio, the lilly pond was the highlight to imbibe spiritual experience. The decorative open air reception was stunning.
Day 2 Kasi Yayharai, Oonjal , muhoortham and Nalangu was exceptional.
Rina‚Äôs Team helped with the display stalls filled with dolls representing cultural values, the Oonjal decorations from a huge tree outside the mutham was amazing and authentic. The floor pathway decorations was fantastic. We were spell bound.

Nevertheless there will be few surprising guests of flies as the venue is surrounded by nature, scented flowers, trees which seems inevitable! We felt blessed by new visitors.

On the whole i would recommend Rina‚Äôs venue for a personalised magical wedding celebration if you are looking for a heavenly traditional authentic memorable celebration üíñ
I thank Rina Nadam, Natchi and all their team members who work tirelessly with perfection bringing unforgettable beautiful memories in your life journey.

Keep going Rina and Team üôèüëçüëå

My daughter‚Äôs marriage was on 6th July 2023, at Rinas Venue, was a great one, with great ambience, traditionally good by the nature of the place, was a very unique one,, other than regular boring marriages, Decorations was excellent with the hands of Mr.Nachi, added more value the place, and very good support by Mr.Vijay from management, Thanks to Madam Rina who personally involved to ensure all arrangements done proper, the whole marriage went very well, left us great memorable one, not only for us, but for everyone who attended our marriage.
As a whole my daughter‚Äôs marriage was  a very memorable and special by the choice of our wedding Venue!! Ever Happy Memories!!!!!

We had a great day on my son's wedding on 6th June at Rina's Venue, wonderful place for Tamilnadu traditional house wedding celebration.  Very good and outstanding support from Mr. Karthik and Mr. Nachi Decorator to make the wedding one of the best memorable in life. All the requirements made in a excellent way.  My family members appreciated and very much satisfied with the Rina's Venue and Decorations. Thank you all and your team.

The food is okay, though the kitchen probably needs some better pest control.  Ola and Ubers are a bit hard to book from the venue so you should get your own transport somehow.

Rina's Venue - it's not just a wedding venue, it's a home away from home to create the best of memories for your special day. The entire property and their management are like a family. They help you take best of the decisions with respect to decoration, space management and finances. Vijay the property manager has exceptional eye for detailing and helps you plan your big day in the most efficient manner. Nachi Anna - the art director for the venue is par excellence. He designed our wedding at par with Jodha Akbar movie set and a lot more. He was awake and there the entire night to make sure things fall in place. Amidst all this not to forget, they help you plan your budget and are transparent with regards to the entire costing and there are no hidden costs.

The venue in itself is beautiful, it gives you a trendy yet cozy feeling unlike other lawn venues, the place feels at home. It's traditional yet modern. It has all the amenities and is a heaven for photographers. There are multiple areas and spots on the property for various events and occasions. A couple of little things we were expecting were that the lights put up in the lawn were not exactly what we wanted and the drapes on the entrance were not changed the following morning. placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the vibrant locality of Triplicane, the Arulmigu Sri Parthasarathyswamy Temple is a stunning 8th-century marvel dedicated to Lord Krishna. This sacred site, revered as one of the 108 Divya Desams, showcases intricate carvings and majestic towers that reflect its rich heritage. The temple's name translates to 'the charioteer of Arjuna,' highlighting Krishna's pivotal role in the Mahabharata.
placeMetadata.address: Car St, Narayana Krishnaraja Puram, Triplicane, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600005, India

reviews.reviewText:
What a temple is this. Loved this. I went this weekend and found one of the beautiful temple. I feel that the temple needs so more cleaning and hygiene due to huge crowd and will work better than now. I really felt blessed to get a chance to visit these places.

The only thing I found about the priests, they are always into rush in any famous temples. Even though less crowd they always ask devotees to go out as fast as they can. But if you see positive sides then one of the best temple to visit in Chennai. Lovely.

The Parthasarathy Temple in Triplicane is one of Chennai‚Äôs most treasured spiritual landmarks. It is one of the 108 Divya Desams. Built in the 8th century by the Pallavas, this temple radiates divinity and preserves the city‚Äôs deep cultural and devotional heritage.

The presiding deity here is Lord Parthasarathy (Krishna as the charioteer of Arjuna). Within the complex you‚Äôll also find shrines of Yoga Narasimha, Lord Rama with Sita and Lakshmana, Lord Lakshmi Ranganatha, Lakshmi Varadaraja, Vedavalli Thayar, and the revered Alwars. The experience is like visiting multiple temples at once, each radiating its own unique energy.

What to Expect:

Atmosphere: Serene yet lively, with devotional chants and the fragrance of incense filling the air.

Parking:Ample space is available for both 2-wheelers and 4-wheelers, which makes visiting convenient even during busy hours.

Shops:Right outside the temple, you‚Äôll find plenty of shops selling traditional items, including vastrams (clothes for vigrahas), flowers, and puja essentials‚Äîperfect if you want to take something back for your home deity.

Photography:Do note that photography is not allowed inside the temple, helping preserve its sanctity.
Nearby Attractions: The iconic Marina Beach is just about 700 meters away, making it easy to combine your spiritual visit with a walk by the sea.

üôè
The Parthasarathy Temple is a place of worship and journey into Chennai‚Äôs soul. Whether you are a devotee, a lover of history, or simply someone seeking peace, this temple is worth experiencing.

‚≠ê Recommended for: Families, devotees, history lovers, and anyone who wants to soak in authentic Chennai tradition.

Arulmigu Sri Parthasarathyswamy Temple ‚Äì Triplicane, Chennai

Visited this ancient temple in central Chennai and was deeply moved by its spiritual ambiance and rich heritage. Here's what stood out:

History & Architecture

One of Chennai‚Äôs oldest surviving temples, originally built by the Pallavas in the 6th‚Äì8th century, then expanded by the Cholas and later Vijayanagara kings  .

A proud Divya Desam, praised in the Naalayira Divya Prabandham by the Alvars  .

Features classic Dravidian structure: towering Raja Gopuram, ornate stone pillars, 36-pillared mandapam, and detailed carvings  .

Multiple Forms of Perumal

Central shrine houses Lord Parthasarathy (Krishna‚ÄìCharioteer of Arjuna), unique with a moustache (‚ÄúMeesai Perumal‚Äù) and holding only a conch (no discus), believed to bear Bheeshma‚Äôs arrow scars from Kurukshetra  .

Other shrines honor Yoga Narasimha, Rama, Gajendra Varadaraja, and Ranganatha, making it a revered Panchamurthi sthalam  .

Meesai Perumal & Variants

The moustached form is an iconic visual; during certain days of Vaikunta Ekadasi, he's shown without a moustache, symbolizing humility  .

The temple also includes a distinct shrine for Yoga Narasimha, with its own entrance and dhvajastambha  .
Prasadam

The Ven Pongal served here is particularly sweet and rich, made with extra ghee and cashews‚Äîbelieved to soothe the deity's arrow wounds  .

Common temple prasadam like Puliyodarai is also loved by devotees  .

Location & Atmosphere

Situated in the heart of Triplicane, just a few minutes from Marina Beach, yet it feels like a peaceful oasis  .

Real devotees comment on its positive aura, dedicated priests, and well-maintained grounds  .

Festivals & Events

Major celebrations include Chittirai Brahmotsavam, Vaikunta Ekadasi, and the Masi (February‚ÄìMarch) Theppam (float festival) in the temple tank  .

The annual Ramanujar festival is significant‚Äîlegend says his father performed a Putrakameshti yagna here and received the blessing that Ramanuja would be born  .

Summary

A divine blend of ancient architecture, living tradition, and deep Vaishnava devotion‚Äîthis temple is high on my list for anyone seeking spiritual depth or historical richness in Chennai. The sight of Meesai Perumal, the serene tank, and the lusciously sweet prasadam make it unforgettable.

An amazing experience. I'm not a religious person but the collective chanting of the mantras and the architectural beauty was enchanting. Whenever you visit Chennai, try this place at least once. You'll get inner peace.
Ancient Hindu Heritage temple. Spectacular South-Indian architecture. The priests are helpful and polite there. Good spiritual and devotional place with peaceful atmosphere.

It's a beautiful temple.of Lord Parthasarathy and Goddess Rukimni. Satyaki's idol is to the left.of Lord Parthasarathy. The speciality is that Lord Parthasarathy has a moustache. He looks cute
Temple is quite old and very beautiful.
There are also temples of Goddess Mahalakshmi and Andal in the premises.

Must see

The Parthasarathy Temple, nestled in the vibrant Triplicane area of Chennai, is an absolute must-visit for anyone seeking a blend of spiritual tranquility, historical richness, and architectural of the oldest temples in Chennai, dedicated to Lord Krishna (as Parthasarathy, the charioteer of Arjuna), it offers a truly immersive experience.

From the moment you step through its towering gopuram, you are enveloped in an atmosphere of devotion. The intricate carvings on the pillars and walls tell tales from Hindu mythology, showcasing the exquisite craftsmanship of the Pallava and later Chola and Vijayanagara periods. The vibrant colors of the deities and the constant chanting of hymns create a serene and uplifting ambiance.

What truly sets this temple apart is its unique dedication to five forms of Vishnu: Krishna (Parthasarathy), Rama, Ranganatha, Gajendra Varadaraja, and Narasimha. Each shrine is beautifully maintained, allowing devotees to offer prayers and admire the distinct iconography. The main deity, Lord Parthasarathy, with his iconic mustache and scars from the Mahabharata war, is particularly captivating.

The temple complex is surprisingly spacious and well-organized, making it easy to navigate. Don't miss the opportunity to witness the daily rituals and aarti, which are performed with great devotion and precision. The spiritual energy during these times is palpable.

Beyond its religious significance, the Parthasarathy Temple is a living testament to South Indian heritage. It's a place where history breathes, art flourishes, and faith resonates deeply. Must visit temple in chennai.

The temple and place is simply divine and awesome. It‚Äôs a bliss to be part of the community and lovely experience of darshans of Parthasarathy Perumal, Narashimar , SriRanganathar, SriKanchiVaradhar and SriRamar swamy.
Also the temple has Goddess Ranganayaki , Vedavalli and Andal thayar.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the bustling heart of Chennai, Guindy National Park stands as a serene oasis amidst urban life. This lush green space, rich in history and biodiversity, was once part of the colonial Guindy Lodge, which served as the residence for British governors. Today, it is recognized as one of India's smallest national parks and offers a delightful escape for families. With its sprawling trees and diverse wildlife, visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls while spotting various animals that call this park home.

reviews.reviewText: Calm, neat and peaceful children's park. Well maintained. Walkway are clean. Drinking water facility and restroom are available inside the park. There are two Kids play area with well maintained equipment's. Many types of birds, reptiles, snakes and animals available. Almost every cabin are filled with sufficient population. Most of the area are covered with trees, so don't worry about the sun. Wheelchair can also go everywhere. Entrance fee sixty for adult and ten rupees for child above 5 years. Paid Car parking available. There is a cafeteria near the entry gate of the park. Inside the park there is no food court available. So better plan accordingly. Go for it if you're looking to spend 2 to 3 hours of time with family.

Guindy National Park, nestled in the heart of Chennai, is one of India's smallest national parks

The park is a sanctuary for a variety of species. An array of bird species, including kingfishers and woodpeckers. The park's diverse plant life further enhances its ecological significance.

The park's serene environment and the opportunity to observe wildlife in their natural habitats. The Children's Park and the adjacent Snake Park are particularly popular among families, offering educational and recreational experiences for children.

The park's size is relatively small compared to other national parks, animals like peacocks and expecting a larger array of species

Timings: The park is open from 9:00 AM to 5:30 PM,

Entry Fees for park

The chance to observe various species make it a worthwhile visit for nature enthusiasts and families

You can just sit around, play games, or have a simple picnic without feeling crowded. It‚Äôs way nicer than being stuck inside the city. If you‚Äôre up for some easygoing time in nature, totally check it out!

Best place with lots of greenery. Kids can enjoy the park and the few animals around. Toilets and drinking water facilities are available in many places, and surprisingly, they are clean and easily accessible. However, I feel there‚Äôs a lack of animals‚Äîonly a few can be seen here. Other than that, it‚Äôs a great place for kids to spend their day. The only downside is that food and snacks inside are a bit costlier compared to outside.

Price Details:
Adult - ‚Çπ60
Below 5 Years - Free

Nice place in the heart of the city. Best part is the cleanliness (rarely seen in a park of this size) and the verdant greenery. Could do with a few more animal species. The huge bird cage which is the star attraction could have been a walk-in structure like other world class zoos and could also do with a flowing water feature given that most of the birds are aquatic. My son really liked the place

It's a good park with smaller animals. Maintained very well. Other than some birds nothing Major here. Kids will enjoy because of the playgrounds. Animals also well fed from the looks of it. Overall Nice place to spend a few hours. I would recommend going on a cloudy days otherwise you will get exhausted from the heat. There are shops outside and inside the park so you can refresh there if needed.
A peaceful green spot in the heart of Chennai. Great for a quick nature walk with family. Kids will enjoy seeing deer, peacocks, and birds. Clean and well-maintained.

Very nice place to hang out with children
Plenty of walking opportunity
Caged animals and birds
Clean and neat. Well maintained
Pretty warm in summer

placeMetadata.name: Fort St. George Museum

sources.snippet: 5 km from city center 25 out of 90 Places To Visit in Chennai. The origin of the great white structure of Fort St. George is inextricable from the history of the city of Chennai itself. Popularly called the 'White Town', the sole purpose of establishing the massive fort compound was to build a British stronghold in the Coromandel Coast and the rest of south India.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Chennai | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: It is a place that should not be missed when on a Chennai tour. Now maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India, St. George Museum was first opened to the public in 1948. Consisting of 3 floors, it presents a rich collection that is displayed in 10 galleries.
sources.shortName: Places to Visit in Chennai

placeMetadata.description: The first British fortress built in India, established in 1644, with a museum & 17th-century church.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Fort St. George Museum, established in 1644, is the first British fortress in India and a significant historical site in Chennai. The museum boasts over 3000 antique artifacts from different periods of modern history and is divided into three floors with ten galleries. Visitors can explore indigenous weapons, a diverse collection of armors, shells fired during World Wars I & II, British Army uniforms, and porcelain articles used during the East India Company era.
placeMetadata.address: Rajaji Rd, near Legislature and Secretariat, Fort St George, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600009, India

reviews.reviewText:
It was a really interesting experience walking through both Indian and British colonial history. The museum is actually inside an old British fort, which adds to the whole vibe. We were especially amazed by all the stuff they had on display‚Äîthings like old weapons, coins, uniforms, documents, and even furniture from the British times.

Security check up would be there.
One can book tickets at the entrance of the museum through QR code.(20 ruppes per adult).

Just a reminder. It's a bit hot indoors.
Also it's only open till 5 pm.

Great museum inside the Fort St George area of Chennai. Good exhibits from the colonial times including guns, cannons, uniforms, medals, coins, ceramics, maps, documents, paintings etc. Gives a glimpse into the history of Chennai and development of British rule in the region. Must visit for history and heritage enthusiasts.

Cons - the only way to get tickets is by online method at the entry of the museum which is quite tedious. Very few fans are inside the museum so it's terrible on a hot day.

Fort St George Museum ‚Äì A Gateway to Colonial Chennai.
A fascinating journey into Chennai‚Äôs colonial past‚Äîrich in artefacts, art, and historical significance.

Filled with galleries showcasing weaponry, coins, uniforms, paintings, documents, and even the first Indian flag hoisted after Independence, the Fort Museum brings history to life through thoughtfully curated exhibits.

The museum is housed in a charming 18th-century structure that once served as the Madras Bank and the Exchange Hall. Upon entering, you‚Äôre greeted by a striking marble statue of Lord Cornwallis‚Äîan iconic landmark and conversation starter.

Ground floor features armaments and porcelain; an upper floor displays portraits, medals, and coins; and the top floor houses the Indian national flag hoisted after Independence.

Well-preserved galleries, especially the detailed craftsmanship on artifacts and colonial ephemera.

The museum can feel quite warm, especially on hot days. Fans are few and spaced out.

Entry ticket can be booked through online link, via QR codes only, at the entrance.

Since the museum lies within a government compound, anticipate police screening. Carry a valid ID. Open from 9 AM to 5 PM. Entry Fee: Rs.20 per head. Bring water, there are limited facilities inside. St Mary‚Äôs Church (‚ÄúWestminster Abbey of the East‚Äù) is worth exploring too.

Nice place to spend 1 to 2 hours with family. Children might enjoy the artifact's.

Free Car parking available across the main road.

Museum inside St. George Fort, Chennai containing all the British era historical artifacts that were preserved. A nominal Rs.20 digital ticket needs to be booked which goes to the government. It's worth of you're a history nerd & want to see the artifacts with your own eyes instead of just reading about it in the books. The data there will satisfy your historical curiosity and increase your knowledge for sure.

The seat of Madras Presidency! While most of the British era building are now govt offices.. this one is a museum!

Gives a peek into the happenings of Madras presidency & it's aftermath. It houses busts of Viceroys and Guv-Generals, coins of that era, cannons, portraits and paintings of places around Chennai.
Never miss the display of the "Oldest preserved National Flag" which was hoisted in 1932. It's amazing!

Carry an ID card for security clearance and the place to close to Broadway bus station and well connected by public transport.

Well preserved. The first fort that East India Company set up on the shores of India and one where its transformation from a trading company to a military force happened under Rober Clive. Currently houses the Tamil Nadu secretariat too but the museum and the church is open for public.

You can clearly understand the history of how Chennai was ruled by the British. However, please note the following: since the site is connected to military facilities, the entrance is on the seaside. You will be asked to show your passport, and security is strict. Tickets are available only through online payment and cost 250 rupees.

Fort St. George Museum preserves the colonial history of Chennai with elegance.
The building itself, a British-era structure, exudes vintage charm and character.
It houses fascinating relics ‚Äî coins, weapons, paintings, and early East India Company records.
The collection of old Madras maps and military artifacts is especially intriguing.
Though not very large, it‚Äôs peaceful and gives a glimpse into the city's colonial past.
A must-visit for history enthusiasts and those curious about Chennai‚Äôs British legacy.

placeMetadata.name: Chennai Rail Museum

sources.snippet: Definitely among the best tourist attractions in Chennai, this museum is a 6.25-acre affair, featuring numerous heritage and technical exhibits. Admire steam engines from the British era and vintage coaches, and enjoy a ride on the toy train. It is one of the most fun places to visit in Chennai for kids.
sources.shortName: 39 Best Places to Visit in Chennai (2024), ‚úîTourist Places List

sources.snippet: Another place to visit if you love to explore the bygone, or historical facts is the Chennai Rail Museum. Located on the New Avadi Road in Lakshmipuram, this museum is spread over an area of 6.25 acres. Here visitors can explore technical as well as heritage aspects of a locomotive or engines.
sources.shortName: Places to Visit in Chennai

placeMetadata.description: Indoor/outdoor museum with displays of vintage engines & coaches, plus miniature train rides.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Located in Perambur, Chennai Rail Museum is a fascinating indoor and outdoor museum showcasing vintage engines, coaches, and miniature train rides. Opened in 2002 on a 6.25-acre site near Villivakkam, the museum boasts a rich rail heritage of India with an impressive collection of steam engines dating back to the British Raj era.
placeMetadata.address: Next to ICF Furnishing Division, New Avadi Rd, Lakshmipuram, Villivakkam, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600038, India

reviews.reviewText: This is an exceptional museum and should be visited by anyone who comes to Chennai. It is clean, well maintained and preserved and has good information for anyone coming to visit it. The grounds are well maintained and the museum is well curated! you can see ongoing preservation works being conducted in front of you which is also cool to see. there is such a breadth of information available in person and such a wide range of equipment on display it is really well done. For a regional railway museum it is a really great experience and I would recommend people definitely visit it if they are around in the future. Purchase ticket at the gate.

A place to know about Railway coach manufacturing and its origin. Recommended place for students.
The railway department can initiate more features to be more interactive and interesting to visitors.
It has a restroom facility, kids play area, Toy train for a short joy ride. Entry fee (includes Toy Train ride) Children Rs 15/- Adults Rs 40/-. Worth a visit. Models created by the waste metal of the train is one good attraction.

Great place to learn about the Heritage of Indian Railways. Recently maintained and well shaded place with lots of trees and lots of play areas. Given the heat the air conditioned model train room was such a relief.

The entry ticket includes a short toy train ride around the entire facility which was a bliss.

Kids will definitely enjoy but be mindful of the summer heat. There's lots of metal all around.

The cafeteria is not operational but there is facility for drinking water.

We visited the Railway Museum recently, and it was a wonderful experience. The museum showcases very old railway engines and a lot of interesting historical facts about trains. There's also a toy train ride inside the museum, which made the visit especially enjoyable for children. A must-visit place in Chennai for both kids and adults!

I visited on a weekday morning with an entry ticket that included a free toy train ride. This place is a great spot if you're into trains. The Chennai Rail Museum has some really old trains and engines on display. I loved walking around and seeing all the vintage stuff, some of them are huge and really old, like from the British times. During my visit, many school students from different schools had come and they were really enjoying it a lot and super excited during the toy train ride. Even I enjoyed it. They also have a restaurant set up inside a train coach, but it was not open during my visit. Overall, it‚Äôs a calm and neat place to visit. If you're in Chennai and want to try something offbeat, this place is worth checking out.

I recently visited the Chennai Rail Museum and was thoroughly impressed! The museum showcases India's rich rail heritage with an impressive collection of vintage locomotives, carriages, and railway artifacts. The exhibits are well-maintained, and the staff is friendly and knowledgeable.

*Highlights of the Visit:*

- *Vintage Locomotives*: The museum has an excellent collection of steam engines and diesel engines, some dating back to the British Raj era.
- *Interactive Exhibits*: The museum features interactive displays, making it an enjoyable learning experience for children and adults alike.
- *Toy Train Ride*: A special highlight of the museum is the toy train ride that takes visitors around the premises, providing a fun and memorable experience.
- *Educational Value*: The museum serves as an excellent resource for understanding the historical significance of railways in India's development.

*Tips for Visitors:*

- *Plan Ahead*: Allocate at least 2-3 hours for your visit to fully explore the exhibits and enjoy the toy train ride.
- *Comfortable Footwear*: Wear comfortable shoes, as the museum grounds are spacious.
- *Photography*: Don't forget your camera; the vintage locomotives and exhibits provide excellent opportunities for photography.

*Value for Money:* ‚Çπ40, including toy train ride is a great deal for the experience offered.

*Overall Experience:* A must-visit destination for railway enthusiasts, families, and anyone interested in India's rail heritage. Highly recommended!"

It's a wonderful place to spend time with family and children
Toy train journey is awesome
Entry fee is available
Better avoid sundays

Must visit this place if you are a railfan.

They have a small souvenir shop inside and have good stock and collection.

This place is good to hangout with kids during weekends.

reviews.reviewText: Great place for families, couples and friends. Crowd control was good. Kids will definitely enjoy. But poor safety measures. Especially the ray fish sections. Parents keep your kids with you all the time.,

Dry rides are kinda ok ,there was only less variety of water games
Tickets are of Rs.850
There is a food court inside and the prices are too high. ( curd rice for Rs.85 )
Restrooms needed improvement, specially the changing room. Most of rides are not active in the afternoon but in evening. Evening vgp rides with lights are so good to see . Overall it was goodüëç

It is a wonderful and peaceful place. I will try again. It is a great place to go here and get peace of mind. You should try to go here with your family.I was here getting ready the whole day and I didn‚Äôt even realize the time.This is not an emotional park, this is a haven, it will fill your heart with happiness. It is a very good place.You should also go with your family. This is a very good place. I will give you five star feedback from my side. This place is very good.

Majority of the rides were not working when I went. And all other rides were not upto the level. I don't know what their maintenance dept is doing. But it had a nice water park. You can enjoy a day with your family and friends.

VGP Marine Kingdom in Chennai offers an incredible experience, especially with its 70-meter underwater tunnel. Walking through this tunnel, surrounded by diverse marine life swimming overhead, was truly mesmerizing. The aquarium is well-maintained and showcases a variety of aquatic species, making it a delightful visit for both adults and children.

My friends and I had a great time at VGP Universal Kingdom! Although some of the main rides were under maintenance due to recent incidents, the experience was still amazing. A few new rides have been opened, and they were absolutely thrilling. The highlight of our visit was the wave pool ‚Äî the DJ kept the energy high, and we spent most of our time enjoying the waves and the water rides. Overall, a fun and refreshing day!.

Best place to spend your holidays with your family and friends. We had a wonderful experience. Kids were thoroughly enjoyed riding  and water parks.

For playing in water games, you have to wear tshirt,  you can bring your own tshirt or  can buy tshirt from there for Rs.100 each. Better to bring your own tshirt, shower cap.

Small birds park also there. You can feed them.

If you bring snacks and lunch with you can spend your whole day. It's very hot during this summer, so cap is must.

We went on weekend only, not much crowded.

Worth for money.

Weekends are fully packed. There is alot of dry and wet activities in the park. Tickets are priced at 850 INR. There is alot of improvement required, the water gets dirty and there is so much dirt in the water. The water activities, the balloon seater is less compared to the crowd, you may have to wait a very long time. Bathroom also need improvement, specially the changing room. Most of rides are out of order or not active. Overall it is good to spend the day.

reviews.reviewText: Food is good and offers a range of options. Not to mention, people would love the atmosphere here. It could be a comforting nook for you amidst a hustle and bustle of the city life. Tea was way better than coffee. Coffee beans they are using are a wee bit on an acid and stronger side with no delicate notes of nuts or chocolate. I recommend main courses and some side menus.

A relaxed place for a lazy reading day with amazing coffee and good food. The place has different sections of seating. Ground floor has women's boutique and first floor has a men's wear section, women's jewellery and cafe. The cafe itself has two partitions. One with beautiful chairs and meant for a date brunch or casual meetings. The second section is more cozy with books lined on shelves and cushioned chairs and sofas. Pick any book you like, read for how ever long you want. Their selection of breakfasts and coffees are definitely worth more visits. Hosts and servers are friendly and helpful with any queries about the menu. The waiting time is fairy short in the mornings but lunch rush will have you waiting for at least twenty minutes. But it's worth all the waiting.
Definitely hungry to try more dishes!

Very calm and neat space for any kind of hangout. Work friendly too! I have a very mixed opinion in food, yes it is overpriced and veg pizza was way too cheesy, sea food pizza was too bland. Only the arabiata pastas were enjoyable but also with extra tanginess. Dessert varieties are as same as wild garden cafe and the taste was üëåüèª. Luxury with a very very average dining and unresponsive service; Keeping the restrooms and washrooms downstairs did not feel very hospitable. Couldn't recommend for a good meal.

We had a lovely experience. The food was great and the ambience was perfect for a cozy night. We tried the Beef tenderloin burger, Carbonara pasta, a chicken quesadilla and a burn basque cheesecake. Really loved the wedges that came with the burger. Everything was delicious.

Pesto penne fantastic! The juices freshly pressed! No oat milk or almond milk available.. (maybe only today?). Mostly men working as waiters (everyone super friendly but where is the gender equality?) would definitely come back.
Lovely ambience. We were really surprised how cozy it was. Food choices were great. Absolutely one of our favourites now to visit often.
This is hands down my favourite cafe in Chennai, no matter how many places I always come back here. I also absolutely adore the cats<3

The atmosphere was very inviting. I loved seeing the old pictures that were displayed on the walls. Food and service was good. If ever I will be able to visit Chennai again, I'll definitely dine here again.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Fika is a trendy cafe and bakery in Chennai that embodies Scandinavian design and the Swedish coffee ritual. The restaurant offers refined European meals and desserts, with a focus on Italian favorites like pastas, anti-pasti, and wood-fired pizzas. Its minimalist yet enchanting garden patio creates an ideal setting for enjoying delicious salads and desserts while basking in the sun. reviews.reviewText:
My recent visit to Fika was nothing short of spectacular! The ambience was warm and inviting, with tasteful d√©cor that created the perfect setting for a relaxed meal. The soft lighting and comfortable seating made it an ideal spot for both casual meetups and intimate gatherings.

I started with their mushroom ravioli pasta which was absolutely divine! The handmade pasta was cooked to perfection with just the right amount of bite, while the mushroom filling was rich and earthy. The cream sauce was delicately seasoned, allowing the natural flavors of the mushrooms to shine through. Each bite was a beautiful balance of textures and flavors.

The Korean cheese bun was a delightful surprise! Warm and fluffy with a crisp exterior, the cheese filling was wonderfully stretchy and flavorful with just a hint of sweetness that complemented the savory elements perfectly. It's clearly a house specialty for good reason.

For dessert, I couldn't resist trying their blueberry pastry and jam cookies. The pastry was buttery and flaky, generously filled with fresh blueberries that burst with natural sweetness. The jam cookies were equally impressive ‚Äì buttery shortbread with a dollop of homemade jam that added just the right amount of fruity tang.

The staff were attentive without being intrusive, offering helpful recommendations and ensuring our experience was memorable. The prices were reasonable considering the quality and portion sizes.

I'm already planning my next visit to try more items from their menu! Fika is definitely a hidden gem worth discovering for anyone looking for a cozy caf√© with outstanding food and welcoming atmosphere.

Visited this place finally, the built in atmosphere is too lovely and good as dreamy and expected :) we went there for lunch along with kids ( they will definitely love being there because of it‚Äôs built)

Some of the staffs were friendly and the person incharge was sweet enough to provide the toddler with some extra balloons they had thank you for the sweet gesture.
Coming to the food , while I was waiting for my friends to join me I ordered dishes like
Chicken strips , rose milk for the kids and that was something preferred for kids. The dish had 5 strips and more fries it was priced at 425 INR. Rose milk 190. Later, we ordered white sauced pasta , red sauced pasta , garden paneer pizza , chickpeas and walnut cutlet each dishes were ranging from 375 to 475 INR , at last we ordered one cold coffee and coconut milk with coffee it was ranging around 275. The food taste was good, the way it was presented was appetising, I personally felt the chicken strips could have better quantity for the pricing and even the chickpeas walnut cutlet was very blunt in taste. Rose milk 190 is too much it‚Äôs way more pricey for it. They can scope down prices for certain dishes.

Service: Service approach is fine but we had to wait for so long to get the orders placed. We could not much waiters visiting us and to check on us. It could have been better if you could improve your terms in service by greeting the customers and to check whether everything was okay. For the pricing and so called experience I strongly suggest this has to be improved. One of the waiter gave us suggestion when I asked something that‚Äôs kids friendly starter I appreciate that. What ever we asked they delivered but the time was lagging
Location. It‚Äôs a great space utilised lively location in a prime place. Very peaceful. But cleanliness level has to be improved. The eaten plates cups are left for longer period I noticed. The curtains were dirty. Kindly take extra care of your things so we also enjoy everything altogether :)

Except certain improvements required we enjoyed being there.

Fika is good but not great!. Yeah you heard me correct. Okay let me break this down for you. Let's start with the ambience. Yes the ambience is actually quite good. They do we have a really cool place with both indoor and outdoor sitting and the place itself is actually spacious enough. They have a really nice ambient lighting and overall the place throws out a positive peaceful vibe. Now let's come to the elephant in the room, the actual food. This one I would say is average. They do have really good food options but if you are a vegetarian then sad news for you there aren't much of options you can choose. We went for Veg Aglio e Olio pasta, Veg cheesy tart and toffee pudding. Pasta was average and the tart was really heavy with a excessive content of butter which was overwhelming. The passing was also kind of average. So in the food department I would say it was really average. Now coming to the price this is also not that good since the prices are on heavier side compared to similar restaurants. So overall it is hard to suggest fika if you are looking for a budget friendly delicious outing.ü•≤

The dessert - blueberry danish was amazing but the korean noodle soup literally had 4 strands of noodles and 4 petty vegetables. That was disappointing.
The price is like for one person 700 around.
The ambience is good.
Service - some of them are good.
Could try for once.

Fika  - Adyar

A stylish and spectacular cafe in Chennai with pretty cool and peaceful ambience. They have both indoor and outdoor seating options.

The menu has variety of delicious dishes and I have tried:
Eggless Tiramisu - yummy and tasty, Blueberry Banana Smoothie - refreshing, Strawberry chilli Shake - not so great, Crunchy Mozzarella - crispy and tasty,
Cheesy sauced Pasta - cheesy and creamy, Four Cheese Pizza - yummy

All the items were great in taste with affordable prices.
A must visit cafe for peaceful vibes.

It's a fancy restaurant that you can visit when you feel like to enjoy the food and ambience. The ambience gave us really cozy and warm feeling. Adding to it, the food was also really good.

Their must try is the Vanilla Panna cotta, it was super delicious. We tried their Fish Fingers but it wasn't up to the mark.

Everything was good but I had to reduce one star due to the price of the dishes. The prices were too high. The dishes aren't satisfying enough for the price they charge.

Also, optional service charge is included in the final bill amount. If you don't wish to pay, you can less that amount and pay the remaining. I didn't like this concept as the service charge was more of like a hidden charge. We noticed it only after paying the bill.
Nice and stylish cafe/restaurant with different sections. Comfortable atmosphere in the outdoor sitting space right at the entrance. Unfortunately most areas were closed or under construction.

What to skip: everything else on the menu.

Place is pretty nevertheless

placeMetadata.name: Koyambedu Market

sources.snippet: Koyambedu Market is one of the biggest perishable goods markets in Asia. Many know it as the flower market due to its size, but the complex consists of more than 3,000 shops, with two blocks devoted to vegetables and one block each for fruits and flowers. The gigantic complex itself has a very unique design from the outside and provides some colorful backdrops up close.

sources.snippet: Koyambedu Market is really big, and most people know it as the flower market. Two blocks are completely devoted to vegetables, another whole block goes for fruits, and yet another for flowers. The complex is gigantic.

While it's famous for its expansive flower market, the complex actually houses over 3,000 shops across different blocks dedicated to vegetables and fruits. Spanning 295 acres, this wholesale market offers an impressive array of fresh produce at both wholesale and retail levels. The unique design of the complex makes it a vibrant and colorful sight to behold.

Koyembedu is one of Asia's largest perishable goods market...happy to have in our Chennai...all types of vegetables available both for retail and wholesale... Koyambedu Market is considered one of Asia‚Äôs largest wholesale markets and stands as a cornerstone of Chennai‚Äôs commerce.

This sprawling complex is situated in the bustling locality called Koyambedu, and is strategically positioned with easy access to key roads and transport hubs, making it a preferred destination for both suppliers and buyers across South India.

As you enter, the sheer size and energy of the market become immediately evident. Countless vendors line the wide lanes, displaying a vibrant variety of fresh vegetables, fruits, and flowers sourced from various farms in Tamil Nadu and other distant states.

The air is filled with a symphony of voices, buyers negotiating in Tamil, lorry drivers unloading produce, and traders organizing their goods for onward sale. Despite its busy atmosphere, the market is fairly organized, divided into dedicated blocks that simplify navigation for seasoned buyers and newcomers alike.

The infrastructure of Koyambedu Market is impressive, with spacious sheds, large storage facilities, and ample parking areas that accommodate heavy-duty vehicles and commercial vans. Hygiene standards have improved over the years, cleaning crews ensure walkways remain passable despite the high foot traffic.

One of the market‚Äôs highlights is its diverse offering. Traders find almost every agricultural commodity imaginable, from common staples like tomatoes, onions, bananas, and coconuts to more exotic produce and regional specialties.

Flower stalls are particularly striking, covering a wide spectrum of colors. Prices remain competitive due to direct-from-farm supply chains, making it a haven for businesses seeking bulk purchases as well as local residents looking for fresh produce at reasonable rates.

Security and safety are visibly prioritized, with surveillance cameras and a vigilant market committee overseeing operations. Early mornings see the market at its liveliest, with peak trading activity, but the pace continues well into the afternoon.

The area surrounding the market hosts a variety of tea stalls, snack shops, and small eateries, offering much-needed respite for traders and shoppers alike.

Koyambedu Market is well connected by the Chennai Metro, local buses, and arterial highways. Accessibility has made it a vital hub not just for Chennai, but for the entire region‚Äôs food distribution network.

Overall, Koyambedu Market is more than just a wholesale market. It reflects the dynamic commercial pulse of Chennai, marrying tradition with modernity in both its scale and operations. It‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone seeking to experience the heart of Tamil Nadu‚Äôs trade culture and the lively spirit of its people.

reviews.reviewText:
The MA Chidambaram Stadium, fondly known as Chepauk Stadium, is one of the most iconic and historic cricket venues in India. Located in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, it holds a special place in the hearts of cricket fans due to its deep-rooted legacy and passionate crowd.

Stepping into Chepauk feels like walking into a temple of cricket. The energy is electric, especially during IPL matches when the yellow sea of Chennai Super Kings fans brings the stadium to life. The roar from the stands when MS Dhoni steps onto the field is truly spine-tingling and something every cricket enthusiast should experience at least once.

The view from the stands is excellent, with well-maintained seating and a layout that gives most spectators a clear view of the action. The upgraded infrastructure and new pavilions have improved the overall comfort and experience. Facilities like clean restrooms, food courts, and accessible entry points make it convenient for families and fans of all ages.

What sets Chepauk apart is the knowledgeable crowd. Fans here appreciate the game beyond just boundaries and sixes ‚Äî even a well-bowled dot ball or a defensive stroke can earn applause. This respect for the sport creates a unique and respectful atmosphere that resonates with players and fans alike.

The stadium is also easily accessible by public transport and offers a great location close to Marina Beach, making the visit even more enjoyable.

In short, Chepauk Stadium is not just a place to watch cricket ‚Äî it's a place to feel cricket. For any die-hard fan, witnessing a match here is nothing short of a dream. The legacy, passion, and pure love for the game make it one of the best stadiums in the country.

I've had the chance to visit the iconic M. A. Chidambaram Stadium twice to watch Chennai Super Kings in action, and each time was electrifying. The atmosphere is absolutely unbeatable ‚Äî the sea of yellow, the deafening cheers for Dhoni, and the pure cricket fever make it a one-of-a-kind experience for any fan.

The stadium itself has a historic vibe and decent facilities. Seating was comfortable enough, though certain stands can get quite hot during day matches. The crowd energy is what makes the place come alive ‚Äî every boundary and wicket is celebrated like a festival.

Entry and exit were managed decently, though it gets a bit chaotic with the crowd. Snacks and refreshments are available, but a bit pricey and the queues can be long.

Overall, if you're a CSK fan or just love live cricket, this stadium should definitely be on your bucket list. Watching a match here is not just about the game ‚Äî it‚Äôs about being part of the yellow army!

M. A. Chidambaram Stadium, commonly known as Chepauk Stadium, is one of India's most historic cricket venues, located in the Chepauk area of Chennai.  Established in 1916, it is the second-oldest international cricket stadium in the country still in use, after Eden Gardens in Kolkata  . The stadium has a seating capacity of approximately 50,000 spectators  . It has witnessed numerous significant cricketing events, including India's first-ever Test victory in 1952 against England and the second-ever tied Test match in cricket history during the 1986 India-Australia series  . The pitch at Chepauk is known to favor spin bowlers, making matches here particularly engaging.  The stadium serves as the home ground for the Tamil Nadu cricket team and the Chennai Super Kings in the Indian Premier League  . Located near Marina Beach, the stadium is easily accessible via public transportation, including the Chepauk MRTS railway station  . Its rich history and vibrant atmosphere make it a must-visit for cricket enthusiasts.

reviews.reviewText:
The Ribbon Building in Chennai is a historic landmark and the headquarters of the Greater Chennai Corporation. It is one of the oldest municipal buildings in India and a prime example of colonial architecture.

It is named after Lord Ripon, the then Viceroy of India, who is regarded as the "Father of Local Self-Government in India."

The Ripon Building was commissioned in 1913 and inaugurated in 1917. The building is spread over an area of 85,000 square feet with three floors. It includes a central clock tower that is 43 meters tall, with a clock known as the Westminster Chime Clock, installed in 1913 and still functional.

It has been the headquarters of the Greater Chennai Corporation since its inception and continues to serve as the administrative hub of the city. The building is a symbol of Chennai's colonial history and urban governance.

Heritage walk within Rippon building: It was an awesome experience walking down madras corporation's history, it's architecture and old heritage. Even though I've been in Chennai since birth this was my first visit

Even portions of the building which are generally not open to public were walked thru

A casual sketch of the Ripon Building turned into reality when I found myself inside it for a heritage walk. My sketchbook feels like pure magic!
The Ripon Building is a stunning example of colonial architecture in Chennai. Its pristine white fa√ßade and intricate detailing make it a visual delight for history and architecture enthusiasts. Walking through its halls during a heritage tour felt like stepping back in time. The building stands as a testament to the city's rich heritage and continues to be an iconic landmark. A must-visit for anyone interested in Chennai‚Äôs architectural gems!

The Ripon Building, an architectural marvel in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, stands as the headquarters of the Greater Chennai Corporation. This iconic white structure, located near the Chennai Central Railway Station, exemplifies neoclassical architecture, blending Ionic and Corinthian styles. It is a significant remnant of British-era construction and a testament to the city's colonial history.

The foundation stone of the Ripon Building was laid in 1909 by the Earl of Minto, then Viceroy and Governor-General of India. Designed by G.S.T. Harris and constructed by Loganatha Mudaliar, the building took four years to complete and was officially commissioned in 1913. It was named after Lord Ripon, the Governor-General of British India, who was known as the father of local self-government.

The building is rectangular in shape, measuring 85 meters in length and 32 meters in width, with a central clock tower rising to a height of 43 meters. The Westminster Quarter chiming clock, installed by Oakes and Co. in 1913, features a mechanical key system and four bells cast by Gillet and Johnston. The structure comprises three floors, with the first floor covering approximately 2,800 square meters. Its walls were built with stock bricks and lime mortar plaster, while the original ground-floor flooring of Cuddapah Slate was later replaced with marble. The roof is supported by teak wood joists, enhancing its durability and aesthetic appeal.

Over time, the Ripon Building has undergone renovations to preserve its grandeur. In September 2015, an annexe building named "Amma Maaligai" was inaugurated behind the main structure. This addition houses various departments of the Chennai Corporation, while the offices of the Mayor and Commissioner continue to operate from the original building. The annexe was constructed with modern sustainability features, including a water-cooled air-conditioning system and heat-reflective roof tiles to reduce energy consumption.

The surrounding area has evolved over the years, with developments such as the Chennai Metro and the modernization of the Central Railway Station complex enhancing the locality's overall appearance. The Ripon Building remains an administrative hub and a symbol of Chennai‚Äôs rich heritage, attracting history and architecture enthusiasts. Though primarily a working office, access to its interiors is generally restricted to official business or special heritage tours.

In front of the building, a well-maintained lawn features statues of Lord Ripon and Sir Thiyagaraya Chetty, further emphasizing its historical significance. The building‚Äôs elegant appearance, intricate detailing, and colonial charm continue to make it a notable landmark in Chennai, representing both its past and its enduring legacy in urban governance.

A very well equipped green matte studio in ECR. Options for black and white backgrounds are also available. Looks cool to shoot
I had my first shoot with the team. Super creative and the lighting equipments available are phenomenal. So happy with the outcome!!
Good calm place, equipped for personal and product  photoshoot
Good place for video production

ops.insert: Bustling urban beach featuring a long shoreline for basking & a variety of food stalls & shops.
Popular beach offering a sandy shoreline & swimming spots, plus the Karl Schmidt Memorial.

Mylapore is an affluent, traditional neighborhood with a number of sacred sites and cultural venues. These include Arulmigu Kapaleeswarar Temple, with its pyramid-shaped tower; the colonial-era Luz Church, with an ornate, frescoed interior; and the Gothic-style Santhome Cathedral, built on the burial site of Saint Thomas. Chennai Lighthouse on sandy Gandhi Beach features a viewing gallery that's open to the public.
State collections including Indian art & sculpture, bronzes, anthropology & a children's section.
Large, medieval-inspired mosque dating to the early 1800s & featuring 5 domes & 2 minarets.

Royapuram Fishing Harbour, also known as Chennai Fishing Harbour or Kasimedu Fishing Harbour, is one of the major fishing grounds for catching fishes and crustaceans located at Kasimedu in the Royapuram area of Chennai, India. Wikipedia.
Serene botanical garden with over 500 species of plants, including exotic varieties.

place.name: The Madras Crocodile Bank Trust and Centre for Herpetology

ops.insert: Longtime reptile zoo & crocodile sanctuary/breeding center with feedings & a night safari.
Cathedral basilica rebuilt in 1896 in neo-Gothic style, at the site of St. Thomas Apostle's tomb.
Vast zoo with large, natural enclosures for Asian mammals & battery-operated cars (fee) for touring.
Modern planetarium with a 360-degree theater for a virtual tour of the night sky & astronomy shows.

Thyagaraya Nagar, known locally as T. Nagar, is a bustling shopping district with stores and street vendors selling colourful saris, gold jewelry and produce at budget prices, especially along Ranganathan Street. The area‚Äôs side streets are dotted with casual eateries and food stalls offering traditional South Indian meals. Close by, elegant art deco bungalows line G.N. Chetty Road.
Renovated in 1920, this Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Muruga is a popular place to get married.
Cross cultural museum featuring 18 historical houses, along with art, crafts & performances.
Monumental Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, known for its health & curative properties.
Former ice store where Swami Vivekananda stayed in 1897, now a permanent exhibition on his life.
Attraction with tracks for walkers & joggers, a children's play area & a seafood restaurant
Large amusement park with rides & a water area with slides & a wave pool, plus 2 restaurants.
Hill with views & a 1523 shrine on the site where St. Thomas was thought to have been martyred.
Sacred 8th-century temple honouring the god Krishna, with ornately carved towers & columns.
Whimsical amusement park with bumper cars, a roller coaster & other rides, plus live entertainment.
Indoor/outdoor museum with displays of vintage engines & coaches, plus miniature train rides.
The first British fortress built in India, established in 1644, with a museum & 17th-century church.
Stylish, vintage-style cafe offering international dishes, salads & breakfast.
Large, tree-filled park with a variety of animals & greenery, plus a children's play area.
Founded in 1916, the country's third oldest cricket stadium is home to the Tamil Nadu cricket team.
Fashionable cafe & bakery with a garden patio serving refined European meals & desserts.
Straight road accessing technology, IT & business campus & its contemporary office blocks & park.

Thiruvanmiyur is a largely residential neighborhood located in the south of Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India. Thiruvanmiyur witnessed a spike in its economy with the construction of Chennai's first dedicated technology office space, the Tidel Information Technology Park in neighboring Taramani. Wikipedia.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Chennai, a vibrant city on the southeastern coast of India, is a treasure trove of stunning photo opportunities that capture its rich culture and natural beauty. From the golden sands of Marina Beach, where the sun dips below the horizon, to the intricate architecture of the Santhome Cathedral Basilica, every corner of this bustling metropolis tells a story waiting to be captured. Whether you're wandering through the lush greenery of Semmozhi Poonga or exploring the historical depths of Fort St. George Museum, Chennai offers a unique blend of modernity and tradition that makes for unforgettable snapshots.

As you stroll through the city, you'll discover hidden gems like the serene Edward Elliot's Beach, perfect for a peaceful sunset shot, or the colorful Shri Ashtalakshmi Temple, where intricate details come alive in photographs. The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the best spots to capture the essence of Chennai, from its lively markets to its tranquil parks. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the best photo spots in this dynamic city, where every click reveals a new facet of its charm.
